ʻʻi	
ʻʻe	
ʻū·pā	
ʻūpēloa	
ʻūmōʻaui	
ʻūmalu	nvi. Brow of a hill or cliff; shade under cliff or hill; to frown, cast shade. Maka ʻūmalu, eyes with heavy upper lids. hoʻo.ʻū.malu To cast a shadow, overshadow, frown.
ʻūlika	vs. Soft, sticky, claylike, glutinous, adhesive, gluey. Kalo ʻūlika, taro that is so glutinous, especially when cold, that it takes much water to grind it by machine, as of the delicious kāī taro.
ʻūlala	vs. Crazy, mad, demented, harmlessly deranged, silly. hoʻū.lala To behave as one crazy; to cause craziness.
ʻūkiukiu	
ʻūhinihone	
ʻōʻōahi	1. Redup. of ʻōahi. 2. n.v. Fire poker or shovel; to poke the fire.
ʻō·hua	
ʻōuili	
ʻōpili	nvs. Cramped or numbed, as by cold or sitting long in one position; aching; clamped together, as leaves of a sensitive plant when touched; a cramp; to clamp or close together. Cf. ʻūpili. ʻŌpili aʻela ia i kona mau wāwae maluna o kahi moe (Kin. 49.33), he drew up his feet into the bed. ho.ʻō.pili To cause a cramp, numbness, etc.
ʻōlenalena	1. n. Yellow, sallow. See lenalena. 2. n. Dye made of ʻōlena plant.
ʻōlelonoʻeau	
ʻōlelo-moana	
ʻōilowai	
ʻōilo	1. nvi. Seedling; to germinate, sprout. 2. n. Young, as of ʻōʻio or of eel. (PEP kooʻilo.)
ʻōhiʻuhiʻu	1. Redup. of ʻōhiʻu. 2. Var. name for blue uhu, parrot fish, so called at Ka-wai-hae, Hawaiʻi.
ʻōhiʻaʻai	
ʻōhiʻa-ʻai	
ʻōhewahewa	Redup. of ʻōhewa; psychotic. ʻŌhewahewa ʻōpulepule, delirium tremens. ʻŌhewahewa ka maka, bleary eyed, glazed eyes. ho.ʻō.hewa.hewa Redup. of hoʻōhewa.
ʻīʻahuʻula	
ʻī-ao	
ʻē·koʻa	
ʻēkake	Var. of kēkake, donkey. Eng. See iākake.
ʻā·nai	
ʻā·mana	
ʻā·keʻa	
ʻā·kea	
ʻāwaʻawaʻa	vs. 1. Uneven, furrowed, craggy. 2. Muscular.
ʻāwaha	nvi. To speak in a rude, harsh manner; rudeness. Pule ʻāwaha, a prayer to bring misfortune.
ʻāpōpō	
ʻāpoʻo	nvi. To hide, seek shelter; to gad about, a gadder.
ʻāpona	vs. Embracing, grasping, catching. Cf. ʻapo 1.
ʻāpiʻipiʻi	1. vs. Wavy, crimpy, kinky, very curly; tempestuous, as waves. 2. n. A kind of seaweed that is tough and not eaten much, perhaps Amansia glomerata.
ʻāpiʻi	1. vs. Curly. 2. n. Tapa-beater design. 3. n. A variety of taro in the piko group, having light-colored corms which are good for poi or table taro; red (ʻula) and white (kea) forms exist; it is called "curly" (ʻāpiʻi) because of crinkles under the leaf. 4. n. A ti plant with green, crinkly leaves.
ʻāpaʻapana	n. Small pieces, fragments. Cf. ʻāpana.
ʻānoa	vi. To end, give up.
ʻāma	
ʻāloʻi	Same as ʻāloʻiloʻi.
ʻālaʻa	1. n. A large endemic tree (Planchonella spp.) with smooth, oblong leaves, shiny-green above, bronze beneath, the fruit yellow or black, to 5 cm long. The sticky, milky sap was used to trap birds, the wood for spears and ʻōʻō handles. (Neal 668.) Also āulu, ʻēlaʻa. (PPN kalaka.) 2. nvt. ʻŌʻō digging stick made of ʻālaʻa or any wood; to prod or dig with a stick, as in taro cultivation. Fig., to dig into the mind; to be dislodged, as by the wind. 3. n. Small corm, as of taro.
ʻālapakona	
ʻākulikuli	1. n. General name for succulent plants. (PCP ka(a)tuli.) 2. A coastal herb (Sesuvium portulacastrum), known in many warm regions, somewhat like wild portulaca (ākulikuli kula), but with longer, narrower leaves, and with small white to magenta flowers at leaf axils. (Neal 340.) 3. Portulaca cyanosperma. Niʻihau.	Same as ʻaeʻae 2.	n. Purslane (Portulaca oleracea), a cosmopolitan weed, a small succulent, prostrate herb, with spatula-shaped leaves and yellow flowers. It is eaten by people, poultry, and stock. (Neal 342.) Lit., plain succulent.	Same as ʻākulikuli kula.	n. Ice plant (Lampranthus glomeratus) from Africa, a low succulent, with thick, narrow leaves, and pink, rose, or orange flowers (used for leis). (Neal 341.)

ʻunu	vt. To shorten, hoist, jerk upwards; to pull or draw together, as the hair. hoʻo.unu Caus/sim.; to massage with the palm of the hand and with quick movements rather than gentle pressure.

ʻuki	n. Coarse native sedges of several genera. See ʻahaniu.	n. All cultivated forms of Gladiolus (as G. blandus), ornamental plants in the iris family, with sword-shaped leaves and one-sided sprays of large colorful flowers. (Neal 235.)

ʻowē	
ʻowakawaka	
ʻowa	
ʻou	1. nvs. Sharp, protruding, piercing; to protrude, project, jut out, pierce, puncture; to reach out for; to stretch out; to sound sharply; pinnacle, high peak; royal; sharp sound as of knee drum or of tapa anvil. Kāne-i-ka-ʻou-aliʻi (Kep. 15), Kāne-of-the-royal-supremacy [a name]. ʻOu ka leo o ka pahu, the voice of the drum sounds. (PCP kou.) 2. n. Bulwer's petrel (Bulweria bulwerii), a small sea bird; for some people, an ʻaumakua. Also ʻouʻou.
ʻoregona	
ʻopū	
ʻopu-kaha-ʻia	
ʻopeʻa-loa	
ʻopala	
ʻonawaliwali	Redup. of ʻōnāwali.
ʻonama	
ʻomega	
ʻomaʻo	
ʻomana	
ʻolonaʻ	
ʻolohe	
ʻoliwa	n. Air plant (Kalanchoe pinnata, also Bryophyllum pinnatum), a succulent growing wild and cultivated in Hawaiʻi and other tropical countries. New plants develop along the edges of the thick scalloped leaves. The tubular green and red flowers hang lantern-like. The Hawaiian name was given because the first plants seen in Hawaiʻi grew near the beach. (Neal 376–8.) Lit., beach-standing olive.
ʻoleʻia	
ʻoleke	
ʻokoe	
ʻoko	
ʻokipoepoe	
ʻoki-oki	
ʻokesa·side	
ʻokanika	vs. Organic (said of the Organic Act). Eng.
ʻoiaʻio	
ʻohawai	
ʻohaikea	
ʻohai	n. The pride of Barbados (Caesalpinia pulcherrima), an ornamental leguminous shrub with red and orange flowers. One variety has yellow flowers. (Neal 432.) Lit., royal ʻohai.	n. The sesban (Sesbania grandiflora), a leguminous tree from tropical Asia with pea-shaped flowers about 7.5 cm long and pods to 60 by 1.3 cm. (Neal 449–50.) Lit., white ʻohai. (PCP koofai.)	n. The royal poinciana (Delonix regia), a legume from Madagascar, one of the showiest ornamental trees in Hawaiʻi because of its bright-red canopy of flowers, which are common and prolific in early summer. One form has yellow flowers. (Neal 430–2.)	n. The red-flowered variety of ʻohai keʻokeʻo (Sesbania grandiflora var. coccinea). (Neal 450.) Lit., red ʻohai.

ʻnʻ	
ʻna	
ʻlke	
ʻiāo	
ʻisi	
ʻiraka	
ʻiolea	vs. Unsocial.
ʻinikiniki	
ʻinaʻina	1. n. Reddish discharge preceding labor in childbirth, amniotic fluid. Ua hemo ka ʻinaʻina o ke keiki, ua kokoke paha i ka manawa e hānau ai, the prebirth matter has been discharged, perhaps the time of birth is near. 2. vs. Tiny ʻina. See ʻina 1.

ʻeziona-gebera	
ʻeweʻewe-iki	
ʻeulāsia	
ʻesetaola	
ʻepesoma	
ʻeneʻenemi	Redup. of ʻenemi. Ā ʻeneʻenemi hoʻi i kona noho hanohano (Nak. 30), opposing his position of honor.
ʻelī	
ʻelizapana	
ʻeliada	
ʻeleʻio	nvi. To go after secretly and speedily; agile, spry; the name of a famous runner of Maui (For. 4:483–7).
ʻelenora	
ʻelehanana	
ʻeleasa	
ʻeleao	n. 1. Plant louse, aphid; germ, blight; blighted, as by ʻeleao. Fig., troublemaker. Ua ʻeleao ʻia ke kalo, the taro is blighted by insects. 2. A native fungus (Gnomania iliau), parasitic on leaf sheaths of sugar cane. 3. Time of light, daylight, a term used in kuwā prayers, as to indicate that a new house is free from taboo and may be occupied. Cf. ʻeleua, kuwā 2. 4. n. Door at the leeward end of a house. Cf. ʻeleua.
ʻekuakolia	
ʻeki	n. Ace. Eng. ʻEki pihulu, ace of spades.
ʻekekeʻi	vs. Short, as a dress or fishline (probably a redup. of ʻeke 2 + -ʻi, transitivizer: Gram. 6.6.4). Cf. mūʻekekeʻi. Lima ʻekekeʻi, short sleeve. Lole wāwae ʻekekeʻi, shorts. Ihu ʻekekeʻi, short wrinkled nose. hō.ʻeke.keʻi To shorten; to pucker up, wrinkle, as the nose.
ʻehunuikaimalino	
ʻehuehu	Redup. of ʻehu 1–4 (this form was perhaps once ehuehu and is sometimes pronounced thus still). Kuʻu hoa i ka ʻehuehu a ka noe, my companion in the spray of mist. Ke ʻehuehu nei nā ʻale, the billows rise in waves [of flaring temper]. ʻEhuehu kai, noho ka moi, where the sea foams, the moi fish lives. (PPN kefukefu.)
ʻehu-nui-kai-malino

ʻasana	
ʻarimataia	
ʻareda	
ʻapi	1. n. Soft spot in the temples; soft part of the human body between the pelvic cone and the lowest rib; under part of an animal's body (sometimes preceded by ke). 2. nvi. A surgeonfish (Acanthurus guttatus), 20 cm long. (PPN hapi.) 3. nvi. Fish gills; to breathe through gills. 4. vi. To palpitate, throb, tremble, shake, quiver; to beat, as the pulse; to stir, as waves; palpitation, quivering. 5. n. A decoy stick basket with a wide opening; it was baited, and after the fish were accustomed to coming for food, a trap was substituted. Ke ao 'ō'ō, ke ʻapi wai (FS 201), the sharp-pointed cloud, the water basket (a cloud full of rain]. 6. To gather together, as people or things. (And.)

ʻanemoku	n. Peninsula. Lit., near island (perhaps a translation of French presqu'île).

ʻanaʻana	1. vs. Pellet-shaped, as goat dung. 2. To shiver, tremble. (And.)

ʻalafereda	
ʻakepa	
ʻakekeke	1. n. Ruddy turnstone (Arenaria interpres), a winter migrant to Hawaiʻi, occurring in small flocks which rise and wheel together. Also keke. 2. vi. To talk loquaciously in a friendly, hospitable manner, bidding a guest to feel at home, make himself comfortable, eat plenty. Cf. heahea. 3. Redup. of ʻākeke, cinder.

ʻainoa	
ʻaikua	
ʻaikola	nvs. Interj. of scorn or derision, especially rejoicing over others' misfortunes, with meaning "serves you right" or "I told you so"; as a verb, to use this term. hō.ʻai.kola To treat contemptuously; to rejoice over the misfortunes of others; sarcastic, contemptible. Hōʻaikola nohoʻi nā lāʻau kaʻa maluna ou (Isa. 14.8), the fir trees rejoice at thee. Hōʻaikola nohoʻi kāu hana you do such contemptible things. (PCP kaitoa.)

weka	n. 1. Ink discharged by squid or octopus. 2. Dark organs of an ʻopihi, a limpet. 3. First dark excreta of an infant, meconium. (PCP weta.) 4. Mucus in the eyes. Also pīheka. 5. Also weta Weight. Eng. Teroe weta, troy weight.

unahe	1. Same as nahe; light breeze. Unahe ka pā o ka makani, the wind blows gently. Hoʻolele lupe i ka unahe (Kep. 115), fly kites in a light breeze. 2. A foliose lichen (Parmelia perlata).

umaumalei	n. A fish similar to but darker than the palani or pualu. It has bright orange-red spots around the gills and side fins and at the base of the caudal fin where the spike is set. Lit., lei [for the] chest.

pūʻainakō	
pūwā	vi. To shine, glitter, reflect brightly, as a night fire. Ua pūwā ka ʻili o kona maka (Puk. 34.30), the skin of his face shone.
pūniu-ʻōhua	
pūmanamana	
pūkō	Same as puaʻō; driven away. Hoʻokahi nō peku ʻana a ka moa mahi, pūkō ana (FS 63), a single kick of the chicken champion, driven off.
pūkuʻikuʻi	Redup. of pūkuʻi. 3. Piha pūkuʻikuʻi, crowded, packed full.

pū-ʻahuʻula	
pōʻōlelo	Short for poʻoʻōlelo.
pōʻaha	1. n. Circle, as of flowers; ring, as of tapa about a sore that prevents friction; a round support for a calabash made of pandanus or ti leaves wrapped into a ring and bound with a cord. Pōʻai ʻia ka pōʻaha a puni i ka pōhaku, the circle was completely encircled by stones. 2. General name for trailing plants.	n. Halo. Lit., light circle.
pō·heo	
pōpōehu	
pōkalani	
pōhākea

pōhaku-o-lama	
pōhaku-o-kauaʻi	
pōhaku-loa	
pīwa	
pīnana	
pīnaki	
pīkaʻo	1. nvs. Dehydrated food, as yam cooked, grated, dried, packed in banana fiber, used on long sea voyages; dried up, juiceless, parched (applied jestingly to old hags). (For. 6:386.) Cf. pokaʻo. 2. n. Canoe hold under both the foreward cover and after cover. Piha nohoʻi ka waʻa mai ka pīkaʻo mua a ka pīkaʻo hope, the canoe was filled from within the bow to within the stern.

pālomi	
pāloke	Same as pālokeloke.
pālauʻeka	nvs. A mere trifle, pittance; worthless, trifling; vagabond, shiftless neʻer-do-well. Kumu kūʻai pālauʻeka, a pittance of a price. Hoʻi pālauʻeka ʻole, come back without even a trifle.
pālaulau	1. Redup. of pālau 3; broad, flat, extended; a wrapper, especially apron or skirt used as a conveyor; to carry in a wrapper. He aha kā ʻoukou pālaulau? He lāʻī nō! What's your wrapper? Just ti leaves. hoʻo.pā.lau.lau Caus/sim. 2. n. Broad, flat part of a paddle or tool, as of a pickaxe, hoe. 3. n. A kind of red fish resembling the ʻūʻū (no data).	Same as pālau moena.	n. Thick, coarse mat on which salt is dried.
pālani	vi. To skim lightly; to paint or daub lightly, especially to paint tapa in light shades. Cf. mālani.
pālanaiki	nvs. Small, compact; slim and trim figure.

puahilohilo	Redup. of puāhilo 1, 2. Hilo, he puahilohilo ke ʻano, no ka mea ʻaʻole i aka loa aʻe kona nui, akā ua mōʻali maʻawe keʻokeʻo iki wale nō (Kep. 99), the lunar night of Hilo, the nature of the moon is a narrow sliver, because its full size has not been made clear, but is just a small white fibrous strand.

pilipa	
pilimai	1. n. A native variety of sugar cane, a yellow-green mutant of ʻakilolo; used in hana aloha, love sorcery, with the prayer for love to cling and hold fast. 2. A variety of taro. 3. A variety of sweet potato.

piihau	
pii-lani	
pihenui	
pihaʻā	1. Same as pīhā 1. Koa pihaʻā, a fallen koa tree suitable for a canoe, so called even though it was not driftwood. Hana a ka wai nui, pihaʻā o kai, when the waters are great, the shorelands are littered with jetsam [said of a person who talks foolishly]. See also mamo 4 and Hal. 102.3. Huʻea i kai nā pihaʻā moe wai o uka, washed to the sea is debris of upland streams. 2. Same as pīhā 2.

paʻapono	
paʻapaʻa	1. n. Dispute, argument, quarrel. hoʻo.paʻa.paʻa To argue, dispute; argument, quarrel. 2. Same as pāpaʻa 1. Ua paʻapaʻa kō lākou alelo i ka make wai (Isa. 41.17), their tongues burned with thirst. (PCP pakapaka.) 3. n. A fish (Dascyllus albisella). 4. n. A kind of sugar cane. Also hoʻopaʻapaʻa.

nolo	1. vs. Filled full, crowded. Nolo ka waʻa i ka iʻa; nolo ka ʻīlio i ka ʻuku, the canoe is full of fish; the dog is full of fleas. 2. Same as nonō.
noketura	
nokekahi	
nokai	
nohomālie	n. The yellow oleander or be-still tree (Thevetia peruviana), an ever-blooming shrub or small tree from tropical America, with long narrow leaves and yellow funnel-shaped flowers. All parts of the plant are poisonous to eat. (Neal 693.) Lit., be still.
nohoanu	n. Native geraniums (Geranium spp.), shrubs and small trees found only at high altitudes in Hawaiʻi. They have small, ovate, green or silvery leaves, edged or tipped with teeth, and reddish or white flowers. Lit., cold dwelling. Cf. hinahina 4.

mōhalapua	n. Blossoming of flowers or youth. Kona lā o ka mōhalapua, his days of blossoming youth.
mī·kā	
mēkia	
mē	vt. To lap, as a dog. E mē i ka wai, to lap up water.
māʻopaʻopa	vs. Tired, aching, of legs; to limp. Ua hele kuʻu mau wāwae ā māʻopaʻopa, my legs are aching. hoʻo.mā.ʻopa.ʻopa Fatiguing.
māʻinoʻino	vi. To deface, mar, spoil, ruin; defamed, defaced. Māʻinoʻino ka helehelena i ka maʻi lēpela, the face is disfigured by leprosy. hoʻo.mā.ʻino.ʻino To defame, slander, deface.
māʻ	
māunu	vi. To molt; to change skin, as of snakes; to change from a chrysalis state, as to a butterfly; to remove bristles, as of a pig for baking. Cf. unuunu.
māpū	n. Ape, baboon.
māniania	Redup. of mania. (PPN maniania.)
māmala'ōlelo	
mālili	1. vs. Blighted, blasted, withered, stunted, as fruits. Hua ʻai mālili (Kanl. 28.22), blasted fruit. (PNP ma(a)lili.) 2. Rare. var. of maʻalili, cooled, calmed. hoʻo.mā.lili Caus/sim. E hoʻomālili ai ka ʻenaʻena, to appease the anger.
mākuaē	
mākea	Same as mahakea 1–3.
mākaʻukaʻu	Redup. of makaʻu. hoʻo.mā.kaʻu.kaʻu To scare, frighten; scared, frightened. (PPN matakutaku.)
mākao	
māhuna	1. nvi. Scaly appearance of the skin, as resulting from excessive kava drinking; to scale thus. (PCP ma(f,s)unga.) 2. n. Fine scented tapa dyed with noni bark, made under strict taboo and reserved for chiefs; used for the best pāʻū (sarongs) on Hawaiʻi. (FS 253.) 3. Var. of māhune 2. 4. n. A variety of taro.
māhinahina	n. Pale moonlight.
māea	1. vi. To rise to the surface. 2. n. A variety of taro. Hawaiʻi.

mano-o-kalanipo	
mano-niho-kahi	
mano-kalani-liilua	
manioka	n. The cassava or manioc (Manihot esculenta), a bushy herb or shrub 1 to 2.8 m high, from Brazil, widely grown for its tuberous, edible roots, like sweet potatoes. The roots also yield a starch, tapioca. Cf. pia manioka. (Neal 513–4.) Eng.
maninini	1. n. Stage of manini, a fish, said to be larger than ʻōhua and smaller than manini. 2. Redup. of manini, to pour.
manini-ʻōwali	
manekineko	
manawahua	1. nvs. Discomfort of the stomach, or indigestion, with gas and often diarrhea, thought to be caused by wrong diet or by excessive handling of animals, such as kittens or puppies, which might also become sick; to suffer thus; great grief, as over the loss of a loved one; to grieve. Lit., swollen stomach. Cf. lūmanawahua. Manawahua kai koʻo, great distress, pain; surging pain, distress [lit., strong sea, stomach discomfort]. 2. n. A native fern (Doryopteris spp.), about 30 cm high, with heart-shaped fronds divided into many long segments. Also ʻiwaʻiwa.

lohena	n. Hearing, obedience. Cf. lohe. He lohena kaʻu i ku ʻolāʻolā (chant), I heard a gurgling.
lohaloha	1. Redup. of loha 1, 3. 2. Var. of lohelohe 2. 3. n. Cocoon.

lelepo	1. Same as lepolepo, dirty. 2. n. Probably another species of Padina, similar in appearance to ʻaʻala-ʻula, a seaweed.

lelea	n. Prayer uttered by a priest as a chief drinks kava, so that the essence of the kava will fly (lele) to the gods. (PPN lelea.)

laʻe	Same as laʻelaʻe 1; pure in sentiment (Hal. 19.8). Cf. kālaʻe. hoʻo.laʻe To clear up, brighten. (PCP lake.)
laʻakona	
laʻakapu	
laē	
lawe·lawe	
lawemai	
laweiaʻi	
laweia'i	
lawe'na	
lawaʻi	
lau·oho	
lau·laha	
laupaʻi	1. Same as laupaʻe. 2. n.v. A great many, multitude, great quantity, heap; to increase, multiply; to have much of; well supplied with. Ua laupaʻi ka hana, there was so much to do. Laupaʻi ka ʻohana, a big family. hoʻo.lau.paʻi To make an abundance, supply, cause an increase, reproduce.
laumaia	
lauloa	n. 1. A variety of taro, said to be the original taro brought to Hawaiʻi. Sometimes poetically called hāloa, long stalk, because a god of that name was said to have been in the form of this taro. This name may be qualified by the terms hāʻeleʻele or ʻeleʻele; ʻeleʻele ʻomaʻo, ʻeleʻele ʻula or palakea ʻeleʻele; hāʻula, koko, ʻulaʻula, or palakea ʻula; uliuli or hāuliuli; keʻokeʻo; manini; ʻōniʻoniʻo; palakea or palakea papamū; pānaʻe; poni (HP 33, TC 3). Cf. hinapū. 2. A variety of sugar cane. When young, yellow-green, striped with light yellow-brown; with exposure, a deep olive, striped with dark brown-red; broad, long, green leaves; large stalks. (HP 222, 225.) 3. Long wave or surf, as extending from one end of the beach to the other. Also kākala.
laulialaa	
laulahi	
laulaau	
lauia	n. A parrotfish (Scarus dubius).
lauhue	n. 1. A variety of poisonous gourd; to spread, of this vine. Hoʻokahi nō Hāwaʻe, lauhue ʻo Kona, only one Hāwaʻe [and] Kona is covered with the poison gourd [Hāwaʻe was an evil sorcerer who prayed many to death; one bad person can poison a whole area]. 2. Var. of lauhua, a fish.

laeʻahi	
laenihi	n. Name applied to various high-headed labroid fishes of the genera Hemipteronotus and Iniistius; this name may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, kea, nēnē, pūkea. Lit., sharp forehead.

kūʻole	
kūʻana	
kūpou	1. vi. To go down, walk downhill fast, stagger; to bend far forward, as one reeling drunk. See kānāwai. 2. n. Cigar wrasse fish (Cheilio inermis). Also poupou.
kūpololū	vs. Vaulting on a long pololū spear.
kūpenu	vt. To dip, to dye by dipping; to sop up; to dab as with a wet cloth; to plunge into water, immerse.
kūpeke	
kūpe	
kūna	
kūmoho	vi. To rise, overflow, as water. Kūmoho piha ke kahawai, the stream water rose full.

kūakamoku	
kōʻie	Similar to kōʻieʻie 2. Kōʻie ʻia akula, carried off by the current.
kōkoʻolau	Var. of koʻokoʻolau, beggar ticks.
kīpalalē	nvi. Disorder, jumble, tumult; rapid flow, as of a swollen stream; disorderly, unsystematic, without method; to spread, extend in a disorderly fashion. Kīpalalē ka ʻōlelo, to talk in a rapid, incoherent manner.
kīlepalepa	Redup. of kīlepa; streamer, banner, tassel.	n. Sugar-cane tassel.
kīlepa	1. vi. To float in the wind, to flutter, flap, flip. Cf. lepa, flag. hoʻo.kī.lepa Caus/sim. 2. vs. Irregular, uneven, of varying lengths. 3. n. Rooster comb, wattle.
kīkēkaʻalā	
kīkoʻu	vt. To cultivate with a hoe or digging stick; to rap or strike with a club; to tap.
kīkoi	vi. 1. Rude, sarcastic. I pane kīkoi mai ai (FS 239), answered rudely. 2. To do in irregular, haphazard fashion, as skipping about while reading; irregular. Mahi kīkoi, to farm scattered unsystematic patches, rather than a complete patch.
kīhau	vi. Frugal, saving; sparingly; to ration carefully. E ʻai kīhau kākou, let's eat sparingly.
kēwā	1. n. Far-off place inhabited try spirits. 2. vt. To anticipate. Ke kēwā nei i ka hōʻea mai o nā malihini, anticipating the coming of the guests.
kēpuka	nvi. Sleight-of-hand trick; to play such tricks. Cf. ʻāpuka, to cheat.

kānenuiākea	
kānekuahine	
kānekopa	
kānekanaka	
kānehoalani	
kānamau	
kāmehaʻi	1. n. A portion of the body (nail, hair, etc., the "bait" of a person believed killed by sorcery, placed in a spot where the supposed murderer will contact it and be killed, as in a bathing place; also used in kuni sorcery. (Kam. 64:126–7.) 2. vs. Unusual, surprising, astonishing. He mea hou kāmehaʻi kēlā, that is surprising news. 3. n. Illegitimate child, since the identity of the father may be unknown.
kālawakua	
kālaihoʻokele	
kālai'āina	
kākuna	
kākai	nvt. Handle, as of a bucket, pot, basket, purse; strings by which a netted (kōkō) calabash is hung; woman's scarf (Niʻihau); to tie on; to encircle with a band, specifically, to stretch the taboo cord before the entrance of a chief's house (this cord was said to fall of its own accord if a relative approached). Kini kākai, pail with a handle.	n. Powder horn, cartridge box.

kuluina	
kuluhau	
kuluaumoe	
kuloli	vs. Having no wife, children, or relatives (name derived from a lone mulberry tree growing in a cave at Kūloli, Kona, Hawaiʻi, which was known as ka wauke kū kahi a Kūloli, the lone mulberry tree of Kūloli); also said of any very young wauke plant.

kuheleimoana	
kuhelani	
kuheilani	
kuaʻā	nvs. Severe taboo on approaching a chief from behind; having such a taboo. Lit., flaming back, perhaps so called because infringement of the taboo was punished by death; a person with this taboo might not lend out any garment that had touched his back, or permit anyone to touch his back. Cf. kuakapu, kualoi, kuapala. He aliʻi kuaʻā kēlā, that is a chief with the back taboo.
kuawehi	n. 1. Dark caterpillar resembling the poko, cutworm, about 5 cm or less in length; it feeds on grass and comes in great numbers. 2. Overexposure to the sun; excessive ultraviolet rays.
kuawaa	
kuasare	
kuapuka	
kuapoʻi	1. n. Weatherboard covering canoe top fore and aft. 2. n. Shell on back of crab or turtle. 3. Kneepan, patella; bone in arm or hand. 4. vs. Full-fledged, feathered out. 5. n. A sea mollusk, Umbraculum sinicum.

kaukoʻo	vt. To walk with a cane (koʻo); to lean on, rely on, depend on. Fig., old and infirm. hoʻo.kau.koʻo To cause to walk with a cane; to walk thus. kahelelani	n. 1. Species of small colored shells, found particularly on Niʻihau; perhaps so called because the shells were used by chiefs. 2. (Cap.) Name of an ancient chief associated with Niʻihau. Lit., the royal going.

hni	
hiʻukole	n. A fresh-water ʻoʻopu fish with a pinkish tail (hiʻu kole). It is taboo to some because it is believed related to the moʻo lizard gods. Also ʻalamoʻo, hiʻuʻula, and nuʻukole.

helemauna	n. A rare native variety of dry-land taro, with dark purplish petioles and white corms; grown on Hawaiʻi. (HP 18, 32.) Also piko ʻeleʻele.

haʻapupū	Same as hoʻopupū. Aloha wale ka maka o aʻu paoʻo, e haʻapupū, e haʻapapaʻa mai nei e ʻai paha, alas, the face of my paoʻo fish, holding back, grasping tight, taking the bait maybe.

haukawewe	Same as kawewe. Haukawewe ke kolopā, nāueue nā hao pine, the crowbars clitter-clatter; the iron pegs shake. Haukawewe hoʻi nā ʻōmaka wai o Kūlani-hākoʻi, the stream sources of Kūlani-hākoʻi pour down.

hauikalani	
hauakalamea	
hauaii	
hase	
haroda	
harbottle

haraguchi	
hapaia	
haokela	
haokea	n. A rather common native variety of taro; the leaves are narrow, the piko, leaf attachment, light, and petioles light green. This taro supplies some gray commercial poi and lūʻau greens. It was formerly used both medicinally and in religious ceremonies, as for dedicating new fish nets. According to HP 17, it is a domesticated form of wild ʻāweu. The name may be qualified by the colors hāʻulaʻula and keʻokeʻo. Var. names reported include ʻahakea, haʻakea, and hāʻawikea.

hameapa	
hameaolae	
hame	n. 1. The two native species of Antidesma, medium-sized trees with hard wood, in the euphorbia family; leaves more or less ovate, fruits in grapelike clusters, purple, one-seeded. Formerly the wood was used for anvils for preparing olonā fiber, the fruit to color tapa red. (Neal 500). Also haʻā, haʻāmaile, hamehame, mehame. 2. Ham. Eng. Also ʻūhā hame, puaʻa hame.

halalē	vs. To slurp, as soup; to eat noisily; to swish, as the sea; to spill or slop over; fat; not clear, as speech. ʻAi halalē, to gobble. Lomaloma ʻai halalē, lazy glutton. Kani halalē, to squawk. ʻO ka ʻōʻio halalē ke kai lā (song), as for the ʻōʻio fish, smacking good the sauce.

alepe	
alena	n. A lowland perennial weed (Boerhaavia repens), with long, thin, prostrate branches, bearing small leaves and flowers. The swollen roots were used medicinally, acting as a diuretic. (Neal 336–7.) Anena on Niʻihau.

ai-manu	
ai'na	
ahuʻawa	n. 1. A sedge (Cyperus javanicus) about .3 to 1.3 m high, with a basal tuft of long narrow leaves and a radiating inflorescence borne at the tip of a long slender stem. (Neal 86–7.) Also ʻehuʻawa, puʻukaʻa haole. Ōpū ʻahuʻawa hānau, born in a clump of ʻahuʻawa [of a humble birthplace]. 2. Another coarse sedge (Cyperus hypochlorus) similar to the preceding one, but with green instead of brown flowers.

ʻūmaupaʻa	
ʻūlōlohi	Same as lohi, slow. Ua ʻūlōlohi loa kāna hele ʻana, his going was very slow.
ʻūlou	
ʻūkake	
ʻō·ʻili	
ʻō·pio·pio	
ʻō·maka	
ʻō·lepe	
ʻō·lapa	
ʻō·kuhi	
ʻōwelawela	Redup. of ʻōwela.
ʻōwehewehe	vi. To open partly, as the clouds.
ʻōpihapiha	nvs. Uncomfortable fullness after overeating; gaseous; somewhat full, as a pool.
ʻōnēnē	1. vs. Fretful, fussy. Cf. nē. ho.ʻō.nē.nē Caus/sim. 2. Rare var. of nūnē, speculation.
ʻōnini	1. nvi. A slight breeze, puff of wind; to gasp for breath, blow softly, blink. Na ka ʻōnini lākou e lawe aku (Isa. 57.13), a breath will take them away. 2. Similar to hulili, dazzling; vibration. 3. n. A kind of surfboard difficult to manage, used by experts. Rare.
ʻōlūlū	nvs. To shake (lūlū) with fat; one who so jiggles.
ʻōle	
ʻōlapalapa	1. Redup. of ʻōlapa 1. Piʻi ʻōlapalapa kona inaina me ka huhū, his wrath flared forth angrily. 2. Same as ʻolapa 2. 3. vs. Full of ravines, projections, cornices, ridges.
ʻōkeni	Same as kenikeni, small change. Ua loaʻa nā wahi ʻōkeni a nā limahana, the workers received some small change.
ʻōkaʻi	1. n. Large night moth. See ex., ʻāolo. 2. nvi. Tendrils of a plant; to grow, interlock, interweave, as tendrils. Cf. wiliʻōkaʻi. 3. Same as kaʻi, procession. See ex., ʻeʻa 1. 4. n. Blossom container of bananas. Cf. ʻeʻa 2. 5. n. Cords on the mouth of a fish net, as for iheihe fish. 6. Small oblong net connecting two larger fish nets. (AP)
ʻōkaʻa	nvi. To revolve, spin; to roll, as a mat; a top; a roll; a dry coconut whose meat has detached itself so as to make a rattling sound. ʻŌkaʻa lau hala, roll of pandanus leaves.
ʻōhānui	
ʻōhinu	1. nvs. Shiny, greasy; piece of roasted meat; roast; grease. Ka ʻōhinu lele uahi manu ē (chant), the grease coming from the bird smoke. 2. vt. To roast or broil lightly. (For. 5:277.)
ʻōhelopapa	
ʻōhelohelo	vs. Pink, rosy, of the color of ʻōhelo berries. He aloha nō nā pua, nā pua ʻōhelohelo, beloved the blossoms, the pink blossoms. hoʻō.helo.helo To color pink.
ʻōhao	1. nvs. Swelling, dropsical condition; swollen. 2. n. Dog's neck. Rare. 3. nvt. To tie, especially a dog by the neck, or lau nets together. Rare. Cf. ʻōhao ʻīlio.	n. Insulting term for kauā, outcasts; they were likened to dogs (ʻīlio) tied (ʻōhao) and waiting to be baked; similarly kauā wore small gourd pendants as insignia that they were to become human sacrifices.
ʻōehuehu	
ʻōaniani	nvi. Very slight stir of air, a breeze; to blow slightly. Cf. ani. He kai mehana no ke ʻōaniani makani ʻole (Kep. 101), it is a very warm sea where there is no breeze stirring.
ʻī·puka	
ʻīpale	
ʻīmaka	n. Watchtower; lookout, observation point.
ʻīmaikalanikalāhele	
ʻīlālāʻole	
ʻēkena	
ʻāʻula	1. vs. Reddish, brownish. Cf. hāʻula. 2. n. An edible seaweed, perhaps the same as limu hāʻula.
ʻāʻiwa	
ʻāʻiliʻili	Redup. of ʻāʻili; spasm.
ʻā·puʻu·puʻu	
ʻā·lika	
ʻā·lani	
ʻā·kili·kai	
ʻāpō	
ʻāpulu	vs. Worn out, as a garment; to show wear and tear; rough, dingy. Hale ʻāpulu, shack.
ʻāpuhi	
ʻāpuakehau	
ʻāpikapika	nvs. Having suction cups, as the tentacles of the octopus; suction cups; spotted.
ʻānapanapa	1. Redup. of ʻanapa. 2. n. Hawaiian soap plant (Colubrina asiatica), a twining shrub, distributed from Africa, India, and Australia to Polynesia, with ovate- to heart-shaped leaves and small round fruits. The leaves form a lather in water and have long been used as soap on Pacific islands. The plant is mistakenly reported to be poisonous. (Neal 541.) Also kauila ʻānapanapa, kukuku; kolokolo on Niʻihau. 3. n. Red seaweeds (Gelidium spp.); small, stiff, branching, edible plants. Also limu loloa.
ʻāmaʻamau	vi. In rapid succession. Cf. maʻamau. ʻĀmaʻamau ka holo o nā kaʻa, the cars followed one behind the other very quickly.
ʻāloaloa	vs. Far, at a distance. hoʻā.loa. loa To keep at a distance.
ʻālaka	
ʻākōlī	
ʻākuleana	vt. To give property or a right to it; to delegate responsibility. hoʻā.kule.ana, Caus/sim. He hōʻailona ia o ka luhi a me ka hoʻākuleana (Kep. 117), this is a sign of toil and of obtaining property.
ʻākaʻakaʻa	Redup. of ʻākaʻa; peeled, as the skin by sunburn or by drinking kava; peeling; ruffled. Fig., exhausted, thin. Kūkae ʻākaʻakaʻa, pellet-like excreta, as of rabbits. Ua māhuna i ka ʻawa, ua ʻākaʻakaʻa, scaly with kava, peeling.
ʻāinā

ʻāinaa

ʻía	
ʻuʻa	1. vs. Useless, unproductive, vain, to no profit, good-for-nothing, worn-out; completely unattractive. Cf. koloʻuʻa, maʻuʻa. Luhi ʻuʻa, vain effort. 2. n. A coarse mat or tapa.
ʻuwehe	
ʻuwaʻu	Var. spelling of ʻuaʻu, petrel.
ʻupaʻupā	Redup. of ʻūpā; to rub clothes up and down a washboard.
ʻuokalani	
ʻuna	
ʻumoki	1. nvt. Cork, stopper, plug, bung; to cork, stop up; wad of a gun; partitions in bamboo water containers; to shoot an arrow so that it hits a mark squarely. See wili wehe ʻumoki. 2. vt. To plant taro shoots in small holes made by a stick. (Kep. 153.)
ʻumi-ka-lani

ʻohia	Pas/imp. of ʻohi 1. ʻOhia mai ā pau pono nā ʻike kumu o Hawaiʻi (chant for Ka-lā-kaua), gather up every bit of the basic knowledge of Hawaiʻi.
ʻoheʻo	
ʻohaohala	1. nvi. A half-truth, exaggeration; to enlarge on certain points; to exaggerate the arguments on one side, but overlook conflicting evidence; dichotomized thinking. Rare. 2. vs. Rank, of lush growth. Rare. 3. Soft, sweet, of melody. (And.)
ʻohaleakalā	
ʻogana	
ʻodeda

ʻo-ae	
ʻmama	
ʻmai	
ʻlwa	
ʻlolani	
ʻliiwahine	
ʻkua	
ʻiʻiwipōlena	
ʻiwaʻiwa	n. 1. All maidenhair ferns (Adiantum spp.), from warm regions of the world, many grown ornamentally. The stems are dark, commonly shiny, slender, wiry; the fronds' subdivisions are four-sided, oblong, or wedge-shaped. (Neal 17–9.) ʻAʻohe i ana iho koʻu makemake i nā ʻiwaʻiwa o ka ua o Hāʻao (hula), my desire is not satisfied for the maidenhair ferns in the Hāʻao rain. (PCP kiwakiwa.) 2. A small, high-mountain fern (Asplenium adiantum-nigrum), with shiny, brown stems and triangular or ovate, subdivided, stiff fronds, the spores numerous, often found covering the under side of the fronds. Known in many countries. 3. Var. name for manawahua 2, ferns (Doryopteris spp.), listed by Rock and Hillebrand.	n. The curly-leaved maidenhair (Adiantum tenerum f. farleyense), an ornamental fern much like the ʻiwaʻiwa hāuli, but the leaf subdivisions much larger, more deeply cut, fringed and overlapping. (Neal 18.) Lit., curly maidenhair. Also ʻiwaʻiwa ʻAukekulalia.	Same as ʻiwaʻiwa ʻāpiʻipiʻi. Lit., Australian maidenhair.	n. The fan maidenhair fern (Adiantum tenerum), with each of the last fan-shaped subdivisions split into five to ten segments.	n. The Venus-hair, a kind of maidenhair fern (Adiantum capillus-veneris), known in many warm countries, both wild and cultivated in Hawaiʻi. The fronds are subdivided into many small, bright-green, fan-shaped divisions, borne on slender, black stems. (Neal 18.) Also ʻiwaʻiwa kahakaha.	Same as ʻiwaʻiwa hāwai. Lit., striped ʻiwaʻiwa.	n. A native fern (Asplenium macraei) with narrow, feather-shaped fronds 30 to 60 cm long, with subdivisions of each frond lobed or scalloped. Lit., small-leafed ʻiwaʻiwa. Also ʻiwa lau liʻi.	n. An endemic fern (Tectaria gaudichaudii) with thin, triangular fronds 30 cm to 1.2 m long, much divided into rather broad lobes. Lit., large-leafed ʻiwaʻiwa.

pūʻuki	
pūʻiki	Var. of pūliki 1.
pūʻia	
pūʻawaliʻi	
pū·ʻolo	
pūweuweu	1. Same as pūpū weuweu. E noho iho i ka pūweuweu, mai hoʻokiʻekiʻe, in the grass clumps, do not be conceited. 2. Same as pūhuluhulu 1, 2.
pūwaikaua	
pūtē	
pūnāwele	vs. Fine, as a spider's web; thin.
pūma	
pūku	
pūkokoʻo	
pūkohukohu	vs. Red, of tapa, as dyed with noni juice (Malo 49). (FS 252–3.)
pūkiʻi	1. vt. To tie. For variants see nīkiʻi. Pūkiʻi waʻa, clamps for binding down the canoe gunwale strake (moʻo) while it was being secured to the canoe. 2. Same as puhikiʻi.
pūkele	1. Var. of ʻūkele, muddy. 2. n. Bushel. Eng.
pūkauaokalākaua	
pūkani	1. n. Fine white leaves in the center of a cluster of pandanus leaves; fine soft sleeping mats made of these leaves. 2. Rare. var of wīkani.	vt. To oppose; strong; intensive of pūkani 2.
pūiki	
pūhili	1. vi. To veer, as the wind. Cf. hili 2. Ke pā pūhili nei ka makani, the wind is blowing every which way. hoʻo.pū.hili To blow in gusts from varying directions. ʻAʻohe mea nāna e hoʻopūhili, he moho no ka lā makani, there is none to blow [him] aside, for he is a wingless rail [or candidate] of a windy day [admiration for one who lets nothing stop him from carrying out a task]. 2. vs. Confused, thwarted, frustrated, set to naught. hoʻo.pū.hili To confuse, thwart, frustrate. 3. Same as pūhilihili, a vine.
pūhaʻuhaʻu	Redup. of puhaʻu. Cf. lima pūhaʻuhaʻu, lole wāwae pūhaʻuhaʻu. Palekoki pūhaʻuhaʻu, large gathered skirt.

pā·kahi	
pāwīwī	
pāwahine	
pātaka	
pāpūhea	n. Dead calm.
pāpua	n.v. To shoot with bow and arrow; archery.
pāpiha	
pāpaʻa-loa	
pāpalu	nvt. Apron, covering, as to conceal nakedness; to cover. Kui ihola lāua i nā lau piku a paʻa, i mau pāpalu no lāua (Kin. 3.7), they sewed fig leaves together, and made themselves aprons.
pāpali	
pāpala-ua	
pānānai	vs. Flat, shallow, as a dish; slim of physique. Also pālānai.
pānui	
pālehua	
pālaumoa	
pākō	
pākiʻi	1. vs. Flat, fallen flat, spread out flat, flattened. Ihu pākiʻi, flat-nosed. Moe pākiʻi, to lie sprawled. hoʻo.pā.kiʻi To flatten out. 2. n. Various flatfishes (Bothus mancus). The name may be qualified by the terms haʻawale and moana. (PCP paatiki.) 3. vs. Broiled, as puppies that were split and laid flat.
pāki	n. 1. Barge. Eng. 2. Also padi Paddy. Eng.
pākele	
pākau	nvt. To place; table, stand. See pākaukau. Fig., beloved. Hoa pākau nohoʻi i ke aloha, companion upon whom [my] love rests.
pāiwi	
pāhā	vt. By fours, four at a time, four times; to distribute to four; to divide by four.
pāhonohono	Redup. of pāhono. hoʻo.pā.hono.hono Redup. of hoʻopāhono.

puʻō	Same as puaʻō; to blaze up, as fire; to bend, as coconut fronds in a wind; to lift up; to bloom. Puʻō ke ahi, the fire blazes up. hoʻo.puʻō Caus/sim.

pukupuku	Redup. of puku 1; wrinkles, crumples, frowning; to wrinkle, frown, purse, as the lips. Pukupuku mai (slang), to fetch, bring. Pukupuku kuʻemaka, wrinkled brow. hoʻo.puku.puku Same as above and transitive. (PPN putuputu.)

pukaamaka	vi. To seal an affinal relationship by the birth of a child. Lit., appear to eye. (Gram. 8.7.2.) Ua pukaamaka mākou me kēlā poʻe, our relationship with those people is sealed by the birth of a child.

pre-mise	
poʻomaikalani	
poʻolā	n. 1. Stevedore. Lit., sun head. 2. The few Hawaiian varieties of small native trees (Claoxylon sandwicense), in the euphorbia family, with soft wood, large oblong, toothed leaves, small clustered flowers, the fruit a three-parted capsule. (Neal 499.) 3. See ʻamaʻama 1, laukea 1.	n. A native species of koʻokoʻolau (Bidens cosmoides), on Kauaʻi only, with yellow flowers 5 cm across.
poʻoku	
poʻokoa	
poʻoa	
poʻo-keʻokeʻo	
poʻipoʻi	Redup. of poi 1, 4, 5; to conceal, as property that one does not want to share with others, or as a secret; to cover up, as the truth; to smother, as a fire; to hush the wailing of a child. hoʻo.poʻi.poʻi Caus/sim. (PCP pokipoki.)

piʻi-a-na-iʻa	
piʻao	
piuta	
pitoma	
pipī	Redup. of pī 2; squinting; twinkling, as stars. Fig., barely surviving. Pipī ka ihu, the nose sniffles and is stopped up. Inā i kanu mau ā mahi mau ke kauwahi ʻāina, ulu pipī wale nō ia lau kanu, if certain lands have been continually planted and farmed, the plants grow feebly. Pipī ka wahie, hoʻonui ka pulupulu, if wood smolders, add more tinder. hoʻo.pipī Caus/sim. to smoke, as ham. Kinai i ka ʻuwiki e hoʻopipī ana (Mat. 12.20), quench a smoldering wick.

palēkō	
palukaluka	
paluhē	nvs. Reduced to pulp, as palu; cooked to a pulp; cooked to the point of failing apart, as meat. Paluhē ka palu, the bait is pulverized; fig., a meek, humble or abused person. hoʻo.palu.hē To make soft, pulpy; to reduce to pulp, cook until soft.
paloma	
palikoolauloa	
palika	1. Also barika n. Carbuncle, (Heb. barakath.) 2. (Cap.) Also Parisa nvs. Paris; Parisian. Eng.
palihai	
paleʻeke	
palepiwa	n. All species of eucalyptus trees. Lit., prevent fever, so called because the leaves were used as fever medicine, and in the pūloʻuloʻu steam bath. Also ʻeukalikia, nuhōlani. ʻAila palepiwa, eucalyptus oil.

palapa	
palao	
palanalelo	
palanaiki	
palamimo	vi. To pilfer quickly, as of a skilled pickpocket; to move easily and noiselessly; to do or act deftly; neatly; swift, neat. Palamimo ka lima i ka ulana, the hand is deft in plaiting. Palamimo ka hoʻonoho ʻana i ka ukana, the gear is packed neatly.
palalā	n. A low or rumbling sound (similar to palalū). Cf. kōhikōhi-kū-palalā (PPN palalaa.)
palaka-a-ka-ʻahu-koheo	
palailai	n. Young of the lai, a fish.
palahēhē	n. Pus. Pakū ka palahēhē, the pus breaks out.
palahē	vs. Fragile, easily torn, as rotting cloth; pulverized, smashed. Moʻa palahē, overcooked to the point of falling apart, as meat. Pōluku ʻia a palahē ke kino, a body pounded and mashed.
palahuli	vi. To turn over, fall over. Palahuli i lalo ka waha ʻai ai (saying), the food-eating mouth is fallen over [said of one in serious trouble]. hoʻo.pala.huli To cause to turn, fall.
palahoana	See puhi palahoana.
pakū	vi. To burst out, break open; squeeze out; crushed. See ex., au 4. hoʻo.pakū To burst, etc.

pakukui	
pakuku	
pakua	
pakohana	Same as kohana; bare. ʻAu pakohana i Wainiha, nā lehua o Luluʻu-pali (song), swimming naked at Wai-niha, are the lehua blossoms of Luluʻu-pali.
pakkage	
pakete	
pakeleke	
pakaulei	vi. 1. To gad about as a vagabond, to live without care or responsibility, carefree; to live wantonly with one mate after another. 2. Same as kaulei, too high or short.
pakauaia	
pakapaka	1. Redup. of paka 3. 2. vs. Many, numerous. Pakapaka ka iʻa a Paulo, Paul has a great lot of fish. 3. Same as ʻōpakapaka 2, 3; wrinkled; scaly. Cf. pakalua.

paholo	
pahipahi	nvi. To slap hands; to play "peas-porridgehot"; this game; a game formerly played by children: a rotten object was buried in the sand and others were asked to dig for it, while the leader said "kōhi kōhi kūpā, no wai, no wai ka lima i hawahawa," gather, gather, dig, whose hands, whose hands are dirtied.

mākā	n. A kind of stone (perhaps pronounced māka).
mākuakua	1. Redup. of makua; aged, old. Ua mākua-kua kēlā kanaka, that person is old. 2. vs. Coarse, thick, as cloth; furrowed, as plowed land. 3. n. A variety of grass. 4. n. Young of mākua, a fish.

lūhaukapawa	
lō·kino	
lōiele	1. nvs. Sluggish, slow; slowness; to loiter, dillydally. Cf. -iele. He aha ke kumu o kou lōiele? Why are you so slow? 2. n. Fool.
līpehe	
līpaheʻe	1. Same as pāheʻeheʻe, a seaweed. Called līpāhoe on Maui. 2. Same as limu lūʻau 1, a seaweed. Kauaʻi.
līlīnoe	
līlīlehua	n. 1. The Texas sage (Salvia coccinea), a weedy herb from southern United States, 30 cm high or more, with toothed, ovate leaves and red flowers, 2.5 cm long, borne in long narrow clusters. (Neal 736.) 2. A variety of taro (no data).
līlā	vs. Spindly, undeveloped, as of plants; thin, as a line of words across a page. Cf. ʻeʻa 2. He maiʻa līlā, ʻaʻohe ʻiʻo, a thin banana without substance [either fruit or plant]. (PPN lila, PCP liilaa.)
lēʻau	
lēluku	
lēhai	Rare var. of lēhei.
lāʻele	n. Old leaf, ready to fall or beginning to dry (a contraction of lau ʻelemakule, old leaf). Fig., aged; old age. Mai ka liko a ka lāʻele, from leaf bud to old leaf.

lepau

lemabouga	
leloa	
lelewa	1. Redup. of lewa 2. (PEP lelewa.) 2. n. Hangers-on about a chief; parasitic persons. 3. (Cap.) Var. of lewalewa 3, Gilbertese.
lelepā	nvt. One who jumps over a fence; to fence jump. Fig., nonconformer; one who cannot be restrained, especially regarding the opposite sex; wanton; to hurdle. ʻO kō pā lā, ʻo lelepā (FS 221), your sty there is one easily vaulted.
lelepuna	
lelepopoulaʻlani	
lelekīkē	
lelekē	vi. To leap here and there. hoʻo.lele.kē A game of tossing ti leaves into Malama Crater at Puna, Hawaiʻi, and dedicating them to Ka-moho-aliʻi.
lelekoaʻe	
lekuka	
leilei	1. vt. To wear a lei or leis. ʻO wai kēia e leilei maila? Who is that wearing a lei there? 2. Redup. of lei 2. hoʻo.lei.lei Redup. of hoʻolei, to scatter, toss about, swing, dandle, as a baby; to juggle; juggling.

la—e—	
laʻolaʻo	1. Redup. of laʻo 1. Laʻolaʻo ka maka i ka lihilihi, to have an eyelash in the eye. Laʻolaʻo kanaka, commoner. 2. n. Lack of satisfaction, even discomfort, resulting from eating unaccustomed or foreign food. 3. n. Kindling; small sticks placed at a break in a bank of a taro patch; trash. 4. vs. Rough, pitted, calloused.
laʻipū	vs. To be peaceful.

lawalawakua	
lauoha	1. n. Sail of a vessel. 2. vs. Dense, lush, of vegetation. Cf. ohaoha. 3. Variation in vision, depending on distance of the object seen. (AP).
laumiha	
laulia	
laukona	n. A variety of sugar cane with green and yellow striped canes and leaves; used in sorcery, because of the meaning of laukōnā, to break the influence of the hana aloha love magic and change love into hatred. Also manini.
laukaʻi	
lauka	
lauele	vi. To wander mentally, imagine. Rare. Cf. -ele.

kūʻauhoe	
kū·ʻē	
kū·pili	
kū·mau

kū·helu	
kūwiliwili	Redup. of kūwili 1.
kūwelu	1. n. Woody shrub with a long tail-like inflorescence resembling cockscomb, perhaps an amaranth. 2. Same as limu loloa 2. 3. Same as kuʻuwelu.
kūpuni	vt. To stand around, surround. Cf. kaʻapuni.
kūpopou	1. Redup. of kūpou 1. Kūpopou ana i ka pali o Kēʻē, going downhill at the cliff of Kēʻē [word play on kē, to object, and ʻē, against; of one who does not cooperate]. 2. Similar to kūpaʻakai. Kauaʻi.
kūpapa	
kūpala	n. 1. An endemic gourd (Sicyos pachycarpa). Cf. ʻānunu and pua-o-Kama. 2. Same as kākū, barracuda. 3. A wild sweet potato or morning-glory with enlarged tuber, eaten in time of famine. Also paha, ʻuala koali. (HP 214). Ka-hoʻolawe, ʻai kūpala, Ka hoʻolawe, eater of kūpala. [Kūpala was eaten here for lack of other food.].
kūpahu	vi. To brace oneself, as while being pushed; to hurl, as a spear. Ua manaʻo ai e kūpahu, a ʻo ʻoe e kulaʻi iaʻu, planning to brace when you push me.
kūnihinihi	Redup. of kūnihi 1, 2. He nohona kūnihinihi kēia, this is a precarious way of life.
kūmāono	
kūmākaha	
kūmāiwa

kūkaepele	n. Sulphur, brimstone, match. Lit., Pele's dung.
kūkae-ʻulaʻula	
kūhōʻailona	
kūhonu	n. An edible spotted-back crab (Portunus sanguinolentus). Lit., turtle back. Also pāpaʻi kūhonu.
kūhewa	nvi. Sudden attack, stroke, as of heart failure; apoplexy; sudden wind gust; suddenly attacked by a stroke; hit without warning or in error; to strike. Makaʻu kūhewa, sudden fear, panic. Pilikia kūhewa, sudden trouble, emergency.

kōhia	Pas/imp. of kōhi. Kōhia mai mākou e ka makani Moaʻe (chant), we were held back by the Moaʻe wind. Kohia aku ka ʻīlio, hold back the dog.
kōauau

kīpoʻopoʻo	nvs. Indented, pitted with holes; pits.
kīpoʻi	vt. To cover, conceal, hide; to protest giving away objects to others. Cf. poʻi, lid.
kīnohi	nvt. Decorated, spotted, ornamented; decoration, ornamentation. Ua kīnohi ʻia ka pāpale me ka lipine ʻulaʻula, the hat is trimmed with a red ribbon. hoʻo.kī.nohi Caus/sim.
kīkīpani	1. n. Conclusion, last, end, every last one. 2. nvi. Severe stomach pains that make breathing difficult; to endure such. ʻAʻole nō he nahu maoli o kona ʻōpū ā kīkīpani hoʻi i kona houpo, it was not a normal ache in his stomach, but a pain that made breathing difficult. E noho maila i loko o ka hauʻoli … ua wehe ʻia ke kīkīpani o ka makemake, living happily … every desire satisfied.

kualana	vi. 1. Lazy, indolent, bored, fatigued; roving about without a chief to support one, as a "floater" (lana); to wander. Lilo ʻoukou i ka ʻōlelo haole ā kualana mākou, since you have all turned to speaking English, we're bored. Kualana ka ʻōpū, very hungry. hoʻo.kua.lana Caus/sim.; to fail in strength. (For. 6:428.) 2. To float on the back; buoyant.

krause	
koʻoloa	n. A native shrub with pale-pink flowers, otherwise like koʻoloa ʻula.	n. A native, hoary shrub (Abutilon menziesii), related to the hibiscus, with heart-shaped leaves 2.5 to 8 cm long, and dark-red flowers from which protrude many stamens borne on a central column. (Neal 550.)

koʻiʻula	n. Rainbow-hued rain, mist, cloud. Ua wili koʻiʻula ka lepo i ka lani mehe puahiohio lā (FS 169), the dirt twirled into the sky like a red cloud in a whirlwind. Hala i ke ala koʻiʻula a Kāne, passed on along the rainbow-hued trail of Kāne [death].

komokomo	1. n. Evil possession resulting from sorcery. Cf. noho. hoʻo.komo.komo To cause a spirit, usually evil, to possess; possession. 2. vt. To fit a garment. hoʻo.komo.komo To dress, as children; to file, put in. (PCP tomotomo.)

komehameha

komaia	
komai	
kolū	n. 1. Glue. Eng. 2. A thorny, weedy shrub (Acacia farnesiana), widespread in the tropics. It is a legume with finely divided leaves and fragrant, round, orange flower heads, used in the perfume industry. The bark yields a gum for glue; sometimes spelled klu. (Neal 406.) 3. Bluing used in washing clothes. Eng. 4. Same as ʻiniko, indigo plant, used for bluing. 5. Screw. Eng.	n. Gauge screws.
kolī	Same as pāʻaila, castor bean or castor-oil plant. The name may be qualified by keʻokeʻo, light-colored, and ʻulaʻula, red. Niʻihau. See castor bean.

kohukohu	1. Redup. of kohu 1. Kohukohu ʻoe i ke kau lio, attractive you are on horseback. hoʻo.kohu.kohu Redup. of hoʻokohu; to pretend, impersonate, disguise, pose; affectation. Hoʻokohukohu kūlana mākaʻikiʻu, impersonation of the office of detective. He hoʻokohukohu hoʻohanohano (Kep. 105), a person pretending to honors not due. Hoʻokohukohu Akua, to put on a show of serving God. Hoʻokohukohu aliʻi, to assume the manners of a chief. 2. Redup. of kohu 2.

kaʻele-huluhulu	
kaʻehuiki	
kaʻaʻokoʻa	1. Var. of kāʻokoʻa. Kaʻaʻokoʻa nō kona manaʻo, his thinking is independent. hoʻo.kaʻa.ʻokoʻa To separate, set apart, refrain, abstain from. ʻO ka mea hoʻokaʻaʻokoʻa i ka lāʻau hahau, ʻoia ke aloha ʻole i kāna keiki (Sol. 13.24), he who spares the rod has no love for his son. 2. vi. Entirely paid, as a debt.
kaʻa·hua	
kaʻawikiwiki	
kaʻauʻamokuokamānele	
kaʻapā	vi. To toss from side to side, as a restless child in bed; in spasms. Eia kuʻu hanu lā ke kaʻapā wale nei nō i ka houpo, here is my breath, panting within the chest.

kauhaʻa	vi. To move up and down as the waves, or as in dancing; to undulate. Aia i Puna-luʻu kaʻu aloha, i ke kai kauhaʻa a ka malihini (song), my sweetheart is at Puna-luʻu, where the sea dances for visitors.

kameʻe	
kameleona	n. Chameleon (RSV), mole (KJV). (Oihk. 11.30.) Jackson's chameleon (Chamaeleo jacksoni) has been noted on Oʻahu since 1972, the green anole lizard (Anolis carolinensis porcatus) since, 1950; this is also commonly called chameleon. (McKeown 28–33.) Eng. See ex., kohu 1.

kamaʻehu	vs. Brownish, reddish-brown. Ua ʻōmea ʻia ke kuahiwi, kū kamaʻehu ʻōwela ulu wela ka lani (For. 6:369), the hill is red-brown, the divine one is red-hot, hot waxing [in anger].

kaka-olelo	
kaiʻopihi	
kaiʻokia	vi. Separated by sea, spared, set apart, separated (see kānāwai). Ma ka inoa o kona kānāwai mau, kaiʻokia kānāwai, no laila, ʻaʻole, he luku hou ʻana a Lono-i-ka-makahiki (For. 4:291), in the name of his customary law, sea-separation law, so there was no more destruction by Lono-i-ka-makahiki. Ke hōʻike mai nei ke akua, ua kaiʻokia ka make o āu mau keiki, the god reveals that your children are spared.

kahikahi	Redup. of kahi 1. (PPN tafitafi.)
kahihi	nvi. Entanglement, perplexity, involvement, blocking; entangled, choked, as by weeds; blocked, involved, as with the law (Mat. 5.40), trapped, framed (slang). Cf. hihi. hoʻo.ka.hihi To entrap, ensnare, entangle, etc.

kahalaʻoaka	
kahalaoweke	
kahakū	1. vi. To turn off one's course; to go where one pleases, trespass. He kahakū wau no kēia ʻāina, iaʻu o uka, iaʻu o kai (FS 235), I may go where I please on this land, inland is mine, seaward is mine. 2. n. A unit of measure, usually said to he about 2.5 m, but in FS 97 called fifteen feet (4.5 m).

iloilo	Redup. of ilo 1, 2; wormy, maggoty; sprouting, germinating. Sorcerers cursed by saying that maggots would eat a victim's body (Kam. 64:123–4).

hūmūkua	
hūkaʻa	n. Pitch, resin, gum from a tree; resinous timber drifting to Hawaiʻi from the northwest coast of America.
hōʻūlōlohi	
hōʻānuʻunuʻu	
hōʻoāʻoā	
hōʻoā	
hōʻonipaʻa	
hōʻomoʻomo	vt. To mold. See ʻomoʻomo.
hōʻolalau	
hōʻoiāʻiʻo	
hōʻikehonua	
hōʻekepue	
hōʻeaʻea	
hōʻawahia	
hōʻawa	1. n. All Hawaiian species of the genus Pittosporum, trees and shrubs with narrow leaves clustered at branch ends, and thick-valved fruits containing many seeds surrounded by a sticky substance (Neal 382–4); considered poisonous (Kam. 64:124, 140). Cf. ʻaʻawa hua kukui. Also hāʻawa. 2. See ʻawa, bitter.	n. A kind of hoʻawa (Pittosporum kauaiense), a tree to 12 m high, found only on Kauaʻi, with large leaves to 25 by 8 cm, more or less downy beneath, and with quadrangular fruits 1.3 cm in diameter.
hōʻanuʻu	
hōʻala	See ʻala, fragrant.

hōʻaeʻae	
hō·ʻoia

hōike

hō'eu	
hēkī	
hēkili	
hāʻula	1. nvs. Reddish. 2. See limu hāʻula.
hāʻueʻue	n. 1. Slate pencil sea urchin (Heterocentrotus mammillatus). Also hāʻueʻue peni, pūnohu. 2. Name in some localities for hāʻukeʻuke, sea urchin. 3. Ringworm.
hāʻaleʻale	Redup. of hāʻale. Hāʻaleʻale i ka puʻuwai, a heart full to the brim [as with love].
hā·ʻule	
hā·ʻina	
hā·lā·wai	
hā·liʻi	
hā·lana	
hāwī	
hāwaʻe	n. 1. A sea urchin (Tripneustes gratilla). Fig., of no character or substance, perhaps so used because of the sayings hāwaʻe kai nui, sea urchin with much juice [and little meat, hence useless], and he hāweʻa ʻiʻo ʻole, sea urchin without meat [or brains]. Varieties of sea urchin are qualified by the terms maoli (natural) and poʻo hina (gray-head). (PNP saawak(e,i).) 2. A kind of stone, used as sinkers for octopus lures. 3. Sprouts from sweet potatoes. 4. (Cap.) Name of a famous evil sorcerer. See lauhue 1, for figurative meaning.
hāpela	
hāpaina	
hāoʻo	
hānunanuna	1. Redup. of hānuna. 2. First fermentation of fresh poi (AP)
hānaukahi	
hāmākuapoko-makawao	
hāmelemele	
hālōnia	
hāloʻi	vi. To well with tears, form pools.
hāloanaka	
hālelo	1. Jagged, rocky; rocks. See ex. papaioa. Kū ka hālelo, ke ʻā o kahawai, rocks and lava in the streams appear [as after a storm; fig., angry words]. 2. n. Coral sea cavern. 3. nvs. Yellowish.
hālalo	1. vt. To place under, lift up from beneath; to give an enema, douche. Kau lī lua i ke anu Wai-ʻaleʻale, he maka hālalo ka lehua maka noe (UL 105), the keen chill of the cold of Wai-ʻaleʻale settles, centers of lehua blossoms are overturned, misty centers. 2. n. Medicine. Cf. hālalo poʻi. 3. vt. To gaze upon, reflect. Hālalo ihola kona maka e ʻimi iā Iēhowa (2 Oihn. 20.3), set himself to seek Jehovah. Hālalo kuʻu naʻau i nā hana (Kekah. 8.9), applied my heart to the tasks.	n. Steaming decoction of herbs, as prescribed for sickness.
hākā	Same as hakakā.	Same as hakakā-a-moa 1,2. hoʻo.hā.kā moa Caus/sim.	v. To quarrel, argue violently.

affairsʻ	
ae—nauwe	
aeʻo	n. 1. Stilts. 2. Hawaiian stilt bird (Himantopus mexicanus knudseni), an endemic subspecies of stilt, formerly common on the main Hawaiian Islands, endangered. Also kukuluaeʻo. 3. Same as kīholo 1, wood fishhook. Kauaʻi.

ʻūpīlaho	
ʻūpīhuʻa	
ʻūpoʻipoʻi	Same as poʻipoʻi. ʻŌʻili maila ʻo ʻAi-ohi-kupua a ma ke alo o Ihu-anu kū ihola, a ua ʻūpoʻipoʻi nā lima (For. 5:409), ʻAi-ohi-kupua appeared before Ihu-anu and stood there and slapped his cupped hands against his body [to resound defiantly].
ʻūpepe	vs. Flat-nosed. Also ʻūmene, kūmene.
ʻūmiʻinalo	
ʻūmiʻilau	
ʻūlū	
ʻūhāpuaʻa	
ʻūhinipule	
ʻūhakihaki	
ʻőiwi	
ʻōʻōkala	
ʻōʻiliʻili	Redup. of ʻōʻili; appearing here and there, once or successively. Ua ʻōʻiliʻili (Kep. 184), rain that comes and goes. (PCP kookilikili.)
ʻōʻilimai	
ʻōʻaki

ʻōpui	
ʻōpiopioo	
ʻōpiokamehameha	
ʻōpikipiki	nvs. Anxiety, mental disturbance; agitated, as the sea. Cf. pikipikiʻō.
ʻōpihihale	
ʻōpalipali	nvs. A place with many precipices; having many cliffs, cliffed; mountainous, hilly.
ʻōpalama	
ʻōpaemahiki	
ʻōpaelolo	
ʻōolelo	
ʻōnoʻonou	Redup. of ʻonou; to force upon. Ka hoʻopiha ʻia ʻana o nā pū me ka pauka a me ka ʻōnoʻonou ʻia ʻana me nā ʻōhelo loloa, guns filled with powder rammed in with long ramrods. ʻAʻohe ia he kāne naʻu i makemake, nāna ka ʻōnoʻonou, he was not the husband I wanted, she forced him on me. ho.ʻō.noʻo.nou Caus/sim.
ʻōnihinihi	n. Small taro shoots, as of the fourth generation. (Kep. 153). See kalo for names of generations.
ʻōmuʻomuʻo	Redup. of ʻōmuʻo; tapering off, dying. Ke ulu ʻōmuʻomuʻo nei ke kō, the cane growth is petering out.
ʻōmuku	nvi. Stump, projection, pommel of a saddle; to project; to cut off short.
ʻōmou	vt. To pin on, attach, fasten securely, as a brooch. See pōkē ʻōmou. Kahi ʻōmou, comb to hold the hair in place or for ornamentation. Kui ʻōmou, stick pin, common pin. Pine ʻōmou, brooch. Pua ʻōmou, corsage. ho.ʻō.mou To cause to pin, to pin, to pretend to pin.
ʻōmilumilu	Same as ʻōmilu.
ʻōmilomilo	Redup. of ʻōmilo. Cf. train 1.
ʻōmaʻolālā	
ʻōmaʻolaulau	
ʻōmaumauikio	
ʻōlē	
ʻōlewa	vs. Swinging. Fig., fickle, changeable, not firmly established or fixed, variable.
ʻōlepolepo	vs. Somewhat dirty, murky, sullied; to sully. Fig., to offend. A kāhiko nohoʻi nā makaʻāinana i ʻole e ʻōlepolepo nā maka o ke aliʻi ke nānā mai (Kep. 165), the commoners were dressed up so as not to offend the eyes of the chiefs who might look upon them. ʻŌlepolepo ka ʻōpū, the stomach is out of order, needs cleansing.
ʻōleloʻia	
ʻōlelomai	
ʻōlelokaulana	
ʻōlelohoʻopaʻa	
ʻōlelohoʻohiki	
ʻōlaʻa-humuʻula	
ʻōkoʻa	
ʻōkoleʻoiʻoia	
ʻōkena	
ʻōhūkai	
ʻōhuka	
ʻōhiʻu	1. Same as ʻōhiki; to dig up the past, especially past sins of others. 2. nvt. Stick used as a needle in thatching; to thatch thus.	n. Toothpick. Lit., probe tooth.
ʻōhiʻa-nui-moe-awakea	
ʻōhiʻa-lehua	
ʻōhiʻa-keʻanae	
ʻōhele	
ʻōhea	1. vs. Drowsy, apathetic, as after eating a big meal. Fig., weak, ineffective. He pua ʻōhea kēnā, kū ʻole i ke kikowaena (song), a weak arrow that of yours, it doesn't hit the bull's eye. 2. Warm, tasteless, as water exposed to the sun.
ʻōahi	n. 1. Rocket, fireworks; clot of burning lava, as from an eruption; hurling firebrands, as from a cliff for ancient Kauaʻi spectacle; flashing lightning. Lit., projecting fire. See ex., kīheʻaheʻa. Nā pali ʻōahi o Makana, the cliffs of Makana, where fire was hurled forth. 2. Rough stone or pumice, as used for polishing surfboards or bowls, or for scraping bristles of a pig (a specimen in the Bishop Museum was made of coral).

ʻī-lālā-ʻole-o-kamehameha	
ʻē·heu	
ʻēkona	
ʻēkakaʻa	
ʻēkaha	n. 1. The bird's-nest fern (Asplenium nidus), widespread in the tropics, forming large rosettes and in some forests perching on branches of trees. The fronds are large, entire, sword-shaped. The black midrib is used like the ʻamaʻu fern for decorating pandanus hats. (Neal 21.) Also ʻākaha. This fern is sometimes called ʻēkaha kuahiwi, mountain ʻēkaha, to distinguish it from the mosses or from ʻēkaha kū moana. (PCP ke(e)ta(f,s)a.) 2. A moss growing on rotted trees. Also limu ʻēkaha. 3. Same as ʻēkaha kū moana.	Same as pākahakaha, a small fern. (Neal 25.)	See ʻēkaha 1.	n. "Black coral" (Antipathes grandis), used medicinally.	n. A native fern (Elaphoglossum alatum), with entire, narrow fronds 24 to 64 cm long and with, close, parallel veins. The spore-bearing fronds are similar but smaller. Cf. hoe-a-Māui.
ʻāʻīkū	1. n. High collar, stiff collar. 2. Spasmodic affection of the neck muscles which draws the head toward the affected side, a torticollis; stiff neck 3. Croup.

ʻālanaka	
ʻālai	
ʻākōlea	1. n. A native fern (Athyrium microphyllum syn. A. poiretianum) with beautiful, large, lacy fronds. See hākonakona 1. (Neal 25.) 2. A small mollusk (Epitonium perplexum). Often called pipipi ʻākōlea or kōlea.

ʻoʻopu-ʻai-lehua	
ʻoʻolu	1. n. Two edible, fragile, red seaweeds (Champia sp. and Chondria tenuissima). They melt in fresh water, hence must be cleaned in sea water. 2. vs. Thin, feeble. 3. Rare frequentative of ʻolu. 4. n. A variety of taro.

ʻelepeli	
ʻelemuku	
ʻelemoe	1. vs. Dark, still, as sea or forest. Kai ʻōmaʻo, ʻelekū, ʻele hiwa, ʻelemoe, ʻelewawā (chant for Ka-lā-kaua), sea green, jet-black, sacred black, silent black, tumultuous black. 2. n. Priests' name for south.

pūʻāʻā	1. vs. Scattered, dispersed; to flee in disorder and fright. Also pūkākā. Holo pūʻāʻā, to scatter in excitement, stampede. hoʻo.pū.ʻā.ʻā To put to flight, drive in confusion. 2. Redup. of pūʻā 2, 5; bundles, sheaths; to tie many; to besiege frequently.

pāpaho	
pāono	vt. By sixes, sixfold; to divide by sixes; to have six or distribute to six. hoʻo.pā.ono Caus/sim.
pāoa	n. The divining rod by which Pele tested the suitability of areas for excavation on the island of Nihoa, at various places on Oʻahu (Salt Lake, Punchbowl, Diamond Head, Maka-puʻu), and on Maui. Finally she planted the staff at Pana-ʻewa, Hawaiʻi, and it became a tree. (PH x–xii.)
pāniki	nvt. 1. To press or pinch the hand or arm, as to attract attention; punch as for paper. Eng. 2. To punish; punishment. Eng.
pānainai	Var. of pānānai. (For.5:385.)
pāmake	vs. Fatal, of disease; to be near death. Lit., touch of death. Cf. pāola.

pākanaka	vs. Tame, accustomed to people, unafraid of people; to know a man carnally; concerning humanity; commoner. Kaʻina mai ke akua pākanaka, he akua kanaka, ua walea wale, he akua kanaka, ʻo ʻoe ia, ē kalani (chant for Ka-lā-kaua), coming along is the god who knows mankind, a human god who pleases himself, a human god, such are you, O heavenly one.

pāhoehoe-nui-a-lonohea	
pāhina	
pāhiahia	
pāhemahema	About the same as hemahema: awkward, unskilled. Pāhemahema i ka hoʻonohonoho ʻana i nā hua ʻōlelo, awkward in the arranging of words, as of one speaking brokenly. hoʻo.pā.hema.hema Same as pāhemahema; to cause awkwardness, to fake lack of skill.
pāheahea	nvt. To call, especially to invite someone to eat; hospitality.

pukaneʻe	
pukanawila	n. Large woody vines (Bougainvillea spp.) from Brazil, bearing during their long flowering time masses of bright-colored bracts, which accompany small hidden flowers. Flower bracts are purple-red, rose-red, brick-red, and orange to whitish. (Neal 337–8.) Eng. Also pua kepalō.

puheke	
puhalu	1. vs. Soft, flabby, loose, sagging, sunken, deflated; to loosen, deflate, sink, sag. Fig., unenthusiastic, relaxed, weak. Also halu, uhalu. Ua puhalu ka pāluna, the balloon collapsed. Puhalu ka ihu, nānā i ke kāʻao, stretch the nostrils, see overripe pandanus fruit [one doesn't see the pandanus until the fruit has fallen and scattered its scent; one appreciates people after they are gone]. hoʻo.puhalu Caus/sim. to pulverize or loosen, as the soil. 2. To stare wide-eyed. (AP)

poʻoʻōlelo	n. Title, as of an article; text, as of a sermon. Lit., speech heading.
poʻo·poʻo	
poʻopuaʻa	n. 1. Head pupil in a hula school. Lit., pig head, so named because the head pupil provided a pig or pig-head offering. Cf. UL 29. 2. Image of a pig, carved of wood such as kukui, placed on the stone heap marking the boundary of an ahupuaʻa land division. 3. Offering. See ex., puaʻa 1.

pokakaʻa	Redup. of pōkaʻa; revolving, gyrating, whirling, spinning; wheel, as on a pulley or cart, swivel. hoʻo.poka.kaʻa To spin, roll, coil, revolve; to repeat the same story over and over.

poiwai

poiolei	
poini	
poinamau	
poime	
pohōpohō	Redup. of pohō 2.
pohāpohā	1. Redup. of pohā, to burst, pop. Cf. kūlina pohāpohā. hoʻo.pohā.pohā Redup. of hoʻopohā. Hoʻopohāpohā nō ia i ka hohonu, mehe ipu hao lā (Ioba 41.31), he makes the deep to boil like a pot. (Cf. Marquesan pohapoha.) 2. n. A kind of passion flower, called running pop (Passiflora foetida), a tropical American weedy vine, the hairy leaves commonly three-lobed; the fruit, enclosed in lacy bracts, is round, red or yellow, popping when crushed. (Neal 599.) 3. n. A non-edible, green seaweed (Dictyosphaeria cavernosa), small, round, hollow, that bursts with a pop when stepped on. Also līpohāpohā pohā.

paʻiʻia	
paʻi·paʻi	
paʻipaʻilima	
paʻiniu	n. 1. Some native Hawaiian lilies (Astelia spp.) with long, narrow, silvery or tan leaves forming rosette-shaped plants growing either on the ground or perching on trees. Small yellow or greenish flowers develop in a panicle on a stalk shorter than the leaves. Formerly, Hawaiians braided hat leis out of the shiny outer layer of the leaves and wore them as a sign that they had visited Kī-lau-ea Volcano, where one species is common. (Neal 192). Also used, rarely, for house thatch (For. 5:655).

papapū	1. n. Row or tier of guns, class of guns. 2. vs. Completely covered, as rocks by shellfish. Papapū ka pōhaku i ka ʻopihi, rock is covered with limpets.

palaleha	vs. Indifferent, careless, slack, neglectful of duty. Cf. paleha. hoʻo.pala.leha Caus/sim. to neglect. ʻO ka lima hoʻopalaleha, he mea ia e ʻilihune ai (Sol. 10.4), he becometh poor that dealeth with a slack hand.

pakipi	
pakemo	Same as pakelo.
pakelo	1. vi. To slip out, as an animal from a trap or a fish from the hand; slippery, slick, slipping, sliding; to thrust, as a spear. See ex., uhu 1. ʻŌlelo pakelo, to talk in a wily, slippery fashion. hoʻo.pakelo Caus/sim. (PCP pa(a)telo.) 2. n. A purgative in which a slimy substance made of hau bark is drunk. 3. n. A seaweed.

painuʻu	vt. 1. To carry on the hip or back, as a heavy child; to lug, as a heavy object that must be hitched up now and then. Ahonui kēia kaikamahine i ka painuʻu i ke kaikaina, this girl is so patient in lugging about her little sister. 2. To boast. See ex., ʻēkā.

nā·nahu	
nā·hele·hele	
nāwāwae	
nāwele	nvs. Fine, threadlike, small; weak, thin; soft, gentle; tracery; softness, gentleness, as of a voice. He ʻike nāwele, seeing just a little; a slight knowledge. Hele maila nō ke ʻala o ka hala, māpu maila nō me ke onaona o ka maile, nāwele pū maila nō me ka huʻihuʻi o ka lehua, there comes the fragrance of the pandanus, wafting thither with the soft sweetness of the maile, and with them a trace of the coolness of the lehua. hoʻo.nā.wele Same as above. Ma ke kamaʻilio hoʻonāwele ʻana, by speaking softly.

nonolo	1. Redup. of nolo; purring. 2. Defeated in war. (AP)
nonohe	vs. Attractive, beautiful. Lehua, ʻo ka lehua maka noe, ua nonohe wale i Hauaʻiliki (chant for Haku-o-Hawaiʻi), lehua, misty-faced lehua, beautiful at Hauaʻiliki.

nomenome	Redup. of nome. hoʻo.nome.nome Redup. of hoʻonome; to move the lips silently, as though speaking to oneself. E hoʻonomenome ʻoe i kō waha ā hiki i ka wā e pau ai kuʻu oli ʻana, mouth your words until I finish my chant.

nohopaipai	
nohonoho	Redup. of noho 2, 3. hoʻo.noho.noho Redup. of hoʻonoho; to pretend to be possessed by a spirit; to arrange, classify, organize. Hoʻonohonoho hou, to reorganize, rearrange. Hoʻonohonoho papa, to classify. Hoʻonohonoho i nā noho, to arrange the chairs. Papa hoʻonohonoho kūlana hana, classification board of positions. Hoʻonohonoho ʻana, arrangement, system. Hoʻonohonoho hoʻolilo, to plan or budget expenses. (PPN nofonofo.)

neʻula	
neʻineʻi	1. Same as neʻeneʻe 1. Rare. hoʻo.neʻi.neʻi Caus/sim. 2. vs. Short, small, as clothes; low-lying, squatting; crowded; to shrink, a small bit, Ke hele neʻineʻi nei, walking with very short steps. Neʻineʻi ka hanu, short of breath. Neʻineʻi ka mea i loaʻa, not much obtained. hoʻo.neʻi.neʻi Caus/sim. 3. Same as naʻenaʻe 1, shrubs or small trees.

nenahai	
neleau	n. The native Hawaiian sumach (Rhus sandwincensis, synonyms R. semilata var. sandwicensis and R. chinesis var. sandwicensis) a shrub or small tree, with light, soft, tough wood. (Neal 525–6.) Also neneleau.
neke	1. n. A fern (Cyclosorus interruptus) found in many tropical countries, somewhat like the kikawaiō, but only half as large. 2. Rare var. of nakeke.

neho	
nehiwa	nvi. Play language, and to use the play language with order of syllables of most words reversed, as nehiwa from wahine, or as in this example: ʻohe uʻo kemakema iā eʻo, for ʻaʻohe oʻu makemake iā ʻoe, I don't like you. Also wehiwa.

naʻi·naʻi	
naʻiliʻilihaele	
naʻili	
naʻiaupuni	
naʻhi	
naʻeua	
naʻenaʻe	1. n. All species of native genus in the daisy family (Dubautia), which are shrubs or small trees with narrow leaves and small yellow, orange, purple, or white flower heads borne in large cone-shaped clusters. (Neal 845.) Also hanupaoa, hina-ʻai-ka-malama, neʻineʻi. 2. vs. Fragrant, as the naʻenaʻe bloom. (But cf. nae, fragrant.) 3. n. Design on outer sheet of a sleeping tapa. 4. n. Fish of surgeon family (Acanthurus olivaceus). 5. vs. Quick, alert.	n. A kind of naʻenaʻe (Dubautia paleata), from Kauaʻi, with large round flower heads, each head with 25 or more light yellow becoming purplish florets. Lit., white-flowered naʻenaʻe.	n. A kind of naʻenaʻe (Dubautia laxa). Lit., yellow-flowered naʻenaʻe.	n. A kind of naʻenaʻe (Dubautia raillardioides) from Kauaʻi, with white to purplish flowers. Lit., red naʻenaʻe.
naʻehe	
naʻauʻauwa	
naʻaumoa	n. Appendix. Lit., chicken intestines. ʻOki ʻia ka naʻaumoa, the appendix was removed.

naiowale	
naioea	n. A native variety of taro, with long, blackish leaf stem; blades large, dark-green; grown in uplands, valued for its red poi. (Whitney 48; HP 25). Also ʻeleʻele and also qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele and ʻulaʻula.

mō-kōlea	
mī·ʻoi	
mīkokoi	1. Redup. of mīkoi. 2. n. A native variety of sugar cane; a lighter brown-red mutant of manulele without purple cast to leaves and sheath. (HP 221.)
mīkana	n. The papaya (Carica papaya), a small tree, a native of tropical America, long popular in Hawaiʻi for its melon-like fruits. (Neal 600–1.) Hawaiʻi. Also hēʻī, milikana, papaia.
mīana	n. Place for urinating (formerly certain places outdoors were set aside for this purpose); urinal.

māʻiʻiʻi	n. 1. A surgeonfish (Acanthurus nigrofuscus). 2. A variety of taro.

māʻana	1. n. Beginning. Rare. hoʻo.mā.ʻana Beginning. (Kep. 175.) 2. Common colloquial pronunciation of māʻona, full.

māuaʻo	
māuaē	
māpumāpu	Redup. and intensifier of māpu. ʻO ka ʻio lele māpumāpu (For. 6:381), the hawk that flies swooping.
māpele	n. 1. Thatched heiau (temple) for the worship of Lono and the increase of food; the offerings were of pigs, not humans. (Malo 160.) 2. A shrub, Cyrtandra cyaneoidea. (Kam. 76:125.) (Cf. For. 6:430, 444.)
māori—pākehā

māmani	
māmalu	1. Redup. of malu; protection, defense, shade, covering; protected, shaded. Māmalu hale o Kū, protection of the house of Kū. hoʻo.mā.malu To protect; to make shady; to cast gloom. 2. n. Umbrella, parasol. 3. n. Type of mushroom.
māmalanui	
māmalamala	
māmakakaiao	
māma	
māluawai	
mālualua	1. vs. Rough, bumpy, uneven, full of ruts or puddles. Cf. lua, hole. 2. (Cap.) n. North wind, known at Maui, Molokaʻi, and Oʻahu. See ex., pāhili.
māloʻo	
mālolokīhākahakuleiʻōhua	
mālipolipo	nvs. Shady; deep, dark shade. Hoʻokakaʻa ʻia mai e ke ahe ka lau mālipolipo, moved by the breezes are the leaves that cast deep shade.
māli	
māleko	
māleka	
mālaʻe	vs. Clear, calm; clear of weeds, as a field; serene, as a cloudless sky. Cf. laʻe, kālaʻe. hoʻo.mā.laʻe To clear, explain clearly; to calm, cheer, dispel gloom; to clear away, as brush or weeds.
mālapua	
mālamamaikaʻi	
mālamamai	
mākōlea

mākuʻu	
mākuakau	
mākuahūnōwai	
mākuahōnōai	
mākouʻīlio	
mākouua	
mākoupōkiʻi	
mākoumau	
mākouhamapuka	
mākoko	1. n. Fresh-water leech or bloodsucker. Cf. koko, blood. 2. vs. Reddish. Cf. heʻe mākoko, loli mākoko. 3. n. A variety of taro, used for red poi. (HP 22.) Also nohu.
mākili	nvs. A drop; to drop, as water. Cf. kilihau, kilihune, Hal. 37.25. He wahi mākili hou, a drop of perspiration. Mākili ʻai, to eat just a little. Mākili liʻiliʻi ka wai (Kep. 165), add a little water [as in mixing poi].
mākela	
mākaukauno	
mākaua	n. War dead (short for make kaua).
mākalano	
mākahi	1. vs. One-eyed (short for maka kahi). See chant, mākole 1. 2. n. Net mesh large enough to admit (the entrance of one finger; a net with such a mesh. Mā kahi ʻoā, mākahi ʻoene, mākahi hoene, a mesh larger than one finger's width, but not large enough for two fingers (mālua).
māilo	nvs. Wasting away of the body; thin, emaciated, as with tuberculosis. hoʻo.mā.ilo To cause thinness. He mea ʻino, hoʻomāilo kino ka ʻopiuma, opium is bad thing that causes the body to waste away.
māikoiko	n. 1. A common variety of sugar cane relished for chewing, named for maiko, a fish; stems blackish; leaves light yellow-green tinged with red; pith dark-brown; seldom flowery. Also ʻeleʻele, kō ʻeleʻele, kauila, nika. (HP 223, 224.) 2. Same as maiko.	n. A variety of sugar cane, a buff-brown and striped maroon when young, becoming olive brown and very deep purple on exposure. Readily mutates to māikoiko. (HP 223.)
māikikalame	
māhuʻia	
māhuʻi	vt. To imitate, ape, pattern after, do as, follow after. Māhuʻi lani (UL 56), royal imitation, said of the right hand in dancing, as this hand always made movements first. hoʻo.mā.huʻi Caus/sim.; to mimic. Poʻe kumu lā, i hoʻomahuʻi ʻia ai e kēlā poʻe (1 Pet. 5.3), teachers imitated by that people.	See māhuʻi.
māholehole	Redup. of mahole. (PPN mafolefole.)

melākou	
melu	1. vs. Soft, decomposed, especially of fish; weakening. ʻAʻohe mai luku ʻē aʻe nāna e melu a nome aku, ʻo ka rama, moekolohe, like pū (chant), no other destructive disease is as weakening and continuing as liquor, adultery, [and] such. hoʻo.melu To cause a decomposition, to leave (as fish) until decomposition begins. Iʻa hoʻomelu, fish, such as hīnālea, slightly decomposed, then salted and seasoned with kukui-nut relish, chili peppers, etc. (PCP melu.) 2. To pull out, as the beard. (And.)

manuu	
manulele	n. A native variety of sugar cane, the stems green striped with yellowish and reddish brown, the pith brown, the leaves purplish. Used medicinally, also in love sorcery. See ex., kāʻawe. (HP 221; Neal 79.) Lit., flying bird.

makawe—li	
makaweliweli	
makawahine	
makauliʻi	vs. 1. Saving, economical, thrifty, provident; miserly, avaricious, eager to own. hoʻo.makau.liʻi To economize; thrifty, saving, economical, frugal; to desire, covet. See ex., kōʻalaʻala. Poʻe hoʻomakauliʻi ʻāina, people eager for land. Ua hoʻokō ʻia ka hana hoʻomakauliʻi i loko o ke aupuni, economies in government have been effected. 2. Broad-backed, thick-shelled, of a turtle.

lō-no	
līʻō	vs. To act wild, as a frightened animal; to open the eyes wide in terror; to quiver, leap away, shy, as a frightened horse. Also leiʻō. hoʻo.lī.ʻō To frighten, cause to shy, leap.

lī·lia	
līpeʻepeʻe	n. Some native species of a genus of edible red seaweeds (Laurencia parvipapillata, L. dotyi, L. succisa), short, with stiff, knobby branchlets, nestling especially in basaltic rock. Also ʻāpeʻepeʻe, hoʻonunu, līpeʻe, peʻepeʻe.

lepohao	nvs. Rust; rusty. Lit., iron dirt.
lepe-a-moa	n. Cockscomb (Celosia argentea var. cristata), an ornamental tropical herb, bearing flowers crowded either on narrow spikes, or in large, plumed clusters, or in odd-shaped, crested combs, the colors including white, yellow, pink, and purple. (Neal 332–3.) Lit., comb like that of a chicken.

laniʻoaka	
lanipō	vs. Dense, dark, lush, as of plants, rain; said of luxuriant growth. Kuʻu haku i ka ua Lanipō-lua, mehe pō lā kā ke anu o ke Koʻolau (chain for Bernice Bishop), my lord in the dark pouring rain like the night and the cold of the Koʻolau [the lord protecting one from darkness and cold]. Maikaʻi ka pā hale i punia i nā pua nani, lanipō i nā mea kanu, how fine the house yard bordered with beautiful flowers, dense with plants.

kūʻululū	vs. Chilled, shivering with cold; shy, abashed. Kūʻululū ka hulu o ka manu i ka ua pehia mai ma ka pali (dance), feathers of the bird are chilled by the rain beating down on the cliff.
kūʻoʻo	
kūʻononui

kūʻe	
kūʻauʻau	vi. To tread water. Lit., stand bathe.

kū·ika·wā	
kū·hō·hō	
kūwili	1. vt. To move restlessly, embrace, pet, caress; to spin in a dance. Cf. kuili, wili 1. 2. n. Implement for piercing an ivory ornament.
kūwalawala	Redup. of kuwala (and kuala); topsyturvy, handspring; to turn cartwheels.
kūwa	
kūpōmakaikaʻeleue	
kūpō	1. nvt. Long net stretched across the track of fish, one end anchored in deep water, the other in shallow (Malo 210, 212); to set a net at night. Cf. kuʻu 2. 2. Scoop net (AP) Also kūpoʻo.
kūpānihi	
kūpākūpā	interj. Boom, boom, as of drums.
kūpunakāne	
kūpona	
kūpololei	
kūpero	
kūpehe	vi. To walk slowly, unsteadily, as of a sick person. Cf. pehe, unsteady.
kūolōlo	
kūolono	
kūolokū	nvi. Trilling song of a bird; to warble, trill. Kūolokū ka leo o ka manu kani leʻa, the voice of the bird singing joyfully is trilling.
kūolo	
kūnanalu	
kūnalohia	
kūmūmū	vs. Dull, blunt, obtuse.
kūmākolu	
kūmākenalihaliha	
kūmāhā	
kūmā-kolu	
kūmā	
kūmoe	Bedstead. Lit., standing bed.
kūmaʻikū	
kūmara	
kūmakani	1. nvs. Windbreak; wind-resisting. 2. Same as ʻaʻaliʻi, a shrub or tree.
kūmakahiki	nvs. Annual, yearly; yearly contract (see ex., lōpā 1). Pua kūmakahiki, annual flower. Hālāwai kumakahiki, annual meeting. Hana kūmakahiki, work on yearly contract.
kūlula	
kūloli	
kūlepe	1. vt. Split open from head to tail, as fish prepared for drying and salting; to slit thus; to hew out roughly, as a canoe; to make a hole or dig out. Kūlepe mai ka mahi ʻai i nā ʻeka lepo (For. 5:683), the farmer dug out blocks of earth [in a taro patch]. 2. vi. To flap, flutter; strong, of wind. Kūlepe nā pepa i ka makani, the papers are flipped about by the wind. Mai kūlepe i kaʻu hana, don't muss up my work. 3. n. Harelip. (Less common than ʻūlepe.)

kūkahaulani

kūkaeʻōhiki	
kūkaenalo	n. 1. Mole on the body, believed to be deposits of flies during infancy. Lit., fly dung. 2. Beeswax. 3. Unbleached muslin. Lio keʻokeʻo kūkaenalo, dusty white horse.

kūholoholopali	
kūhinu	nvt. Greasy, oily, polished; to rub with oil, polish, grease; a name applied to women (except kāhuna) because they were not permitted to make offerings to the gods with their hands (Kep. 23).

kŋkiri	
kīʻenenei	Var. of kīʻelelei.
kīī	
kī·ʻoʻe	
kī·wī	
kī·wila	
kī·puni	
kī·poʻo·poʻo	
kī·peku	
kī·paku	
kī·lepa·lepa	
kī·lau·ea	
kī·kī	
kī·kē·kē	
kī·kolu	
kī·kala	
kīwīkona	
kīwalaʻōikekapu	
kīwalawala	Same as kiwalaʻō.
kīpūkai	n. Seaside heliotrope (Heliotropium curassavicum), a prostrate, perennial American herb 30 to 60 cm long, with narrow, hoary leaves, white or pale purple flowers, considered indigenous to Hawaiʻi. Formerly the plants were dried and brewed for tea used as a tonic. (Neal 718.) Also nena and poʻopoʻohina or lau poʻopoʻohina on Niʻihau.
kīpāhoehoe-kaulanamauna	
kīpohopoho	1. Redup. of kīpoho. 2. n. Small arable patch surrounded by lava beds, smaller than a kīpuka.
kīpapa-a-ola	
kīnaʻuhale	
kīmō	vt. To pound, bruise, mash, as with stick or stone; to smash, break into bits; to dub out the inside of a canoe log with an adze, tamping and smoothing the surface; to crack, as nuts. Also kīpō. hoʻo.kī.mō Caus/sim. Rare.
kīloiwale	
kīloii	
kīloa	vt. To put away for safekeeping, as bundles on a shelf. Rare.
kīlaueaka	
kīlau	n. 1. Bracken or brake (Pteridium aquilinum var. decompositum), a cosmopolitan, stiff, weedy fern, with creeping underground stems and long-stemmed, triangular fronds 60 or more cm long, much divided. (Neal 15–6.) Also kīlau pueo, paiʻā. 2. Ti stalk with shredded leaves, as held by a fishing director (kilo iʻa) and used to guide the fishing canoes; ti stalk used to flip water of purification.
kīkēʻia	
kīkēnuiaʻewa	
kīkēkē—a	
kīkēana	
kīkaua	
kīkahō	1. vi. To splash. 2. To speak or interrupt rudely.
kīhāpai-ʻewa	
kīhoe	nvi. To lead a roving life, without fixed abode, wander; vagabond.
kīhewa-moku	
kīhelei	Short for kiʻihelei.
kīheipūkoʻa	
kīauau	1. Redup. of kīau. 2. Interj. encouraging workers, as in drawing an unfinished canoe hull from the forest to the shed at the seashore where it was to be completed. Pau kēia kīauau ʻana a ke keiki (Nak. 62), after the boy's chant urging fast action. Kīauau, kīauau, kīauau! holo auau, holo auau, holo auau! (canoe-hauling chant), fast, fast, fast! run quick, run quick, run quick! 3. vt. To smooth out wrinkles from tapa or clothes with light, deft touches.

kāʻiewe	n. Group of relatives who faithfully serve and care for a chief during illness; perhaps related to ʻiewe, placenta.

kuʻielua	
kuʻialauahi	
kuʻe·maka	
kuānea	1. vs. Lonely, forsaken, barren, desolate, dreary. Fig., awkward, unintelligent, ignorant. Cf. kuākuānea, ʻōnea. hoʻo.kuā.nea To make lonely, barren. Fig., to behave ignorantly; to cause boredom, dreariness; boring. He hana hoʻokuānea, a boring act. 2. (Cap.) n. Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)
kuza	
kuwā	1. vi. To make a din, talk loudly, resound. See wā 3 and chant, kūmaumau 3. He leo paha no ka ʻiʻiwi e kuwā nei, perhaps voices of ʻiʻiwi birds making a din. 2. n. Prayer for special events, as trimming grass from over the door of a grass house, or completion of a new canoe or net. (Malo 184.) See ʻeleao 3.

kulukuluʻā	n. 1. Sap from green kukui nuts, used to prevent infections in cuts and as a gargle for sore throat and thrush. 2. (Cap.) Name of a legendary chief at Hilo. (FS 251.)
kulukau	
kului	vi. 1. To drip (kulu 1 + -i, transitivizer). Hilo ua kului ua (Nak. 28), Hilo with rain, dripping rain. (PPN tuluʻi.) 2. To be late at night. (For. 6:420.) Cf. kulu 7.

kule-ana	
kula—kū	
kulaʻōlelo	
kulaʻi-mano	
kulapepeiao	n. 1. Earring. Lit., gold [for] ears. Kula pepeiao hoaka, crescent-shaped earrings. Kulapepeiao kolū, earrings held in place by a screw. Kulapepeiao lewalewa, dangling earrings. Kulapepeiao ʻūmiʻi, earrings for unpierced ears; lit., clamped earrings. 2. Fuchsia (Fuchsia magellanica), an introduced plant so called because of resemblance of flower to an earring. (Neal 650.) 3. Same as aloalo koʻakoʻa. Niʻihau. 4. Modern name for cocoon. 5. Same as līpepeiao, a seaweed.

kulali	
kulakulaʻimai	
kulakulai	
kulakula	1. Redup. of kula 1; fields. (Gram. 8.6.) Ua hiki aku kāua i kulakula, we have reached the open fields [a place to stop]. Kāpae aʻe nō i kulakula, just set aside in the fields [never mind, just put it aside, don't worry]. Kū loa akula i kulakula, stopped away up in the fields [stranded]. 2. n. Game like ninepins.

kualo	1. vt. To block, obstruct, hinder (less used than ālai). He aha lā hoʻi kāu i kualo mai nei? Why are you standing in front of me? 2. Also sualo n. Swallow. Eng.

kuakala	n. Medicine made of pua kala plant and taken as treatment for pyorrhea, neuralgia, stomach ulcers.
