kuakahiki	
kuaiwi	n. 1. Long, straight, stone wall. Niʻihau. 2. Same as kuāuna.
kuaiolaloa	
kuaina	n. Twine, string. Eng.
kuailo	vt. To give up, as a riddle; to be unable to answer; expression used in riddling. The person who can not guess a riddle says: Kuailo! I can't guess the answer, you tell me. If the riddler doesn't want to give the answer, he may reply tartly: ʻEu nō ka ilo, make! Maggots move! Defeated! Kuailo ʻana, answer. Ā penei ke kuailo ʻana (Kel. 90), this is the answer.
kuaihelumoa

kuahuula	
kuahulu	1. Same as koali kua hulu, a morning-glory. 2. nvt. Any wild vegetable eaten in time of famine; to eat such.
kuahui	1. n. Supporting rods for house purlins (Kam. 76:98), brace. Also ʻaho piʻo kuahui. 2. vt. To cooperate, work together. E kuahui aʻe kākou i ka hana, we are cooperating in the work.
kuahonu	Same as kūhonu, a crab.

kilipue	vt. To embrace tightly, hug ardently. I kēlā wā i ala aʻe ai ua kanaka nei a ʻike ihola he pōhaku kā kāna e kilipue nei, then the man awoke and saw that it was a stone he was embracing ardently.

kele-akiu	
kelaudina	
kelanakila	
kelamoku	1. n. Sailor. Lit., ship sailor (Eng.). 2. n. Checkered jacket; the material from which it is made. 3. nvi. A hula step invented by Hawaiian sailors: one foot swings alternately on ball and heel of foot, the other points with the toe front and back four times, then reversed; knees are bent, arms out, bent at elbows with hands up and fingers often snapping, swaying with the body; to dance thus.

kaʻāwela	
kaʻānapali	
kaʻānaniʻau	Same as ahupuaʻa, the altar marking the land division. Oʻahu. Rare.
kaʻwa	
kaʻupenikala	
kaʻunē	vs. Slow, lagging, delaying.
kaʻumiʻumi	
kaʻumikūmāhā	
kaʻumeaʻai	
kaʻulupūlehu	
kaʻuluhao	
kaʻulaʻulaokalani	
kaʻula-hea-nui-o-ka-moku	
kaʻukaʻu	1. nvi. To slow down, delay, procrastinate, hesitate, linger; inhibited, checked; reluctance. He aha ka mea o ke kaʻukaʻu ʻana? Why be hesitant? hoʻo.kaʻu.kaʻu To cause delay, linger. 2. n. Hemorrhoid or exterior obstruction to bowel evacuation.	Intensifier of kaʻukaʻu. Kaʻukaʻu lua ʻole, dauntless, quick, alert. Kuʻupau nā hana i ke ākea, kaʻukaʻu lua ʻole i ka lehulehu (drinking song), unrestrained doings in public, unchecked by the crowd.

kaʻuamoa

kaʻoaʻopa	
kaʻo	vs. Dry, arid, bare of vegetation, as of deserts (usually not used alone). Cf. pōkaʻo, kaʻokaʻo.
kaʻiʻini	
kaʻiālupe	vt. To support a sick or intoxicated person between two other persons. Lit., lead like a kite. Same as kauālupe.

kaʻianaaʻahuʻula	
kaʻeʻoi	
kaʻeʻe	vi. Hard, stiff, not soft or or pliable; dried up withered as by heat; evaporated. He wahi wai ʻaʻohe i kaʻeʻe i ka lā, a little water not evaporated by the sun.

kaʻa·wili·wili	
kaʻa·wili	
kaʻa·wale	
kaʻawiliwili	
kaʻawili	vt. To turn, twist, writhe as in pain; to knead, as bread (Ier. 7.18). (ʻŌpelu fish that form a vertical wall as they swim, flapping to maintain this unusual position, are said to kaʻawili). Cf. pākaʻawili. hoʻo.kaʻa.wili To cause pain (Ier. 4.19); to torture; to cause to twist or writhe; to fondle or pet in ardent love-making.	n. 1. Lathe. 2. Perfumer (RSV), apothecary (KJV). (Puk. 37.29.) More commonly kāwili lāʻau.

kaumea	
kaumanu	1. n. Paper mulberry too old to be used for tapa 2. Method of catching birds by tying a caterpillar and a stick at one end of a string; when the bird swallows the caterpillar the stick lodges in his throat.

kanonui	
kanono	1. vi. To whack, bang, smack, as of a blow; to receive such a resounding blow. Kanono akula kou lae, your forehead is smacked with a blow. Kanono kona hoʻopaʻi, he was lambasted a severe penalty; his punishment was a blow. 2. n. Red chicken.

kanikaniʻāʻula	1. n. Insomnia. 2. vi. To mourn in chanting. E ʻai aku ʻoe i ʻole hoʻi kēlā e kanikaniāʻula wale mai, eat or he will mournfully chant. 3. (Cap.) n. Name of a star.

kalana-honuʻ-a-kama	
kalamoho	n. 1. A kind of awa, a fish. 2. Cliffbrake (Pellaea ternifolia), a short, slender fern, the fronds with short, paired, narrow divisions. It grows in dry, sunny places, as at Kī-lau-ea Volcano. Also kalamoho lau liʻi.

kahapouli	n. Taboo on menstruating women, restricting them to the menstruating house. Lit., place of dark night.

ipu-wai-a-hoa-lani

ipu-auau	
ipomea	
ipolani	
ipoipo	vt. To make love (less used than hoʻoipoipo). hoʻo.ipo.ipo To make love, court, woo; love; romantic. Hoʻokela o ka hoʻoipoipo, fantastic love making. Hoʻoipoipo ʻana, courtship. Mele hoʻoipoipo, love song. Ka ʻahaʻaina hoʻoipoipo (1 Pet. 4.3), revelings. Ka poʻe hoʻoipoipo (Heb. 13.4), whoremongers. (PEP ipoipo.)

ikūlanakauhale	
ikū	n. Officer, as in a society. Several types are listed below. Rare.	n. Chairman. Lit., speaking officer.	n. Secretary.	n. Highest officer, head, president.	n. Chief of rank below the hoa aliʻi descendants of Kāne; chiefs of this rank could rule as mōʻī but were not considered divine. (For. 6:266.) But cf. mōʻī .	n. Genealogy of chiefs of the hoa aliʻi class (descendants of Kāne), the highest of all. (For. 6:266.)

hō·ʻono·ʻono	
hō·ʻolu	
hō·ʻano	
hō·mona	
hō·lapu	
hō·kū·naʻi	
hōpue	n. 1. Orange finch (Psittirostra palmeri), the largest of the Hawaiian finchlike forms, found only in the Kona and Kaʻū districts, Hawaiʻi. 2. A native tree, endemic to Kauaʻi (Urera sandvicensis var. kauaiensis), in the nettle family, with broad-ovate, long-stemmed leaves, and red, clustered, male flowers. Also hona, ōpuhe.

hōkuli	
hōkio	n. Small gourd whistle; flute [RSV], pipe [KJV] (1 Sam. 10.5); to whistle.	nvi. To whistle with hands cupped over the mouth; such a whistle. (Pūeoeo is said to be the sound of the whistle.)

hāʻuleʻo	
hāʻuleāpaʻa	
hāʻulehope	
hāʻiuʻiu	nvs. High, height. Cf. ʻiuʻiu. (FS 201.)
hāʻeleʻele	nvs. Blackish.
hāʻaʻa	Same as ʻaʻaʻa, fibrous.
hāʻawipiowale	
hāʻawiaholo	
hāʻawenui	
hāʻ	
hā·ʻoi	
hā·ʻawi	
hā·ʻae	
hā·nuku	
hāuna-pō	
hāuli	1. nvs. Blackish, swarthy, dark. 2. n. Bruise. Ka hāuli o ka mea hewa ʻole, he nalowale koke, a bruise inflicted on an innocent person vanishes quickly. 3. n. Small fish with formerly transparent body beginning to darken; embryo of human or animal.
hāpuʻupuʻu	1. n. Young hāpuʻu ferns that have not yet developed trunks. 2. n. Young stage of hāpuʻu fish. 3. Same as ʻāpuʻupuʻu; rough, bumpy, pimpled; impediment, as of speech; to speak with an impediment; obscured, as by mist. 4. n. A mound, as for playing marbles. Also haʻapuʻu, hoʻopuʻupuʻu. 5. Same as hāʻupuʻupu, sweet potato sprouts. 6. Same as hāpuʻu, taro: the plant is said to be distinguished by its leaf stems: yellow-green above, and dark brownish on lower half. The corms yield good light-colored poi, the leaves good greens. This name is qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, and maoli. (HP 17, 32.)

hāli'ali'a	
hāleu	nvt. Toilet paper or anything so used; to wipe, as with toilet paper. Ua hāleu ʻole, a rain without toilet paper [so sudden that there is not time to use toilet paper]. (PPN faʻelu.)

hāinu

hāhāmau	vt. To catch fish with the hands, as in crevices.

hupu	n. Collection; catch, as of fish. (This rare word is not clear. ʻO nā mea hupu apau loa, ua kapu ia mau mea, ʻaʻole e hiki ke kiʻi ā lawe wale, as for everything caught [?], these things are taboo and cannot be sought and carried off without permission.

huopakele	
huoi	n. Suspicion. Rare. hoʻo.huoi To suspect, surmise distrust; suspicion. Ka huwā, ka paio, ka nuku, ka hoʻohuoi ʻino (1 Tim. 6:4), envy, strife, railings, evil surmisings.

hialoa	vs. Well trained, skilled. ʻO mākou nā ʻōlohe āiwaiwa hialoa ma ka lā, we are the most wondrously skilled experts of the day.

haʻulena	n. A falling, dropping. Hōʻiliʻili i nā haʻulena o kāu ʻai (Oihk. 19.9), to gather the gleanings of your harvest.

haiku-uka	
haikamaio	
haikala	n. 1. Severe cramps, said to have often proved fatal. 2. Asthma. (For. 6:451.)	n. Cramps, less severe than haikala.
haikaika	nvi. To make faces; a grimace of defiance and contempt; the corners of the mouth were drawn back tightly, the teeth separated, chin and lower teeth twisting from side to side; perhaps the figure-eight mouthed images were inspired by this violent fighting expression. Cf. ikaika, strong, hoʻo.hai.kaika. A less violent grimace than haikaika; to make faces, cause to make faces.
haika	1. Same as haikaika. 2. vi. To gasp. Rare.

ʻʻai	
ʻūʻōki	
ʻūʻuʻu	Same as ʻūʻū 1. Ka poʻe ʻūʻuʻu (Isa. 32.4), the stammerers. Ua ʻūʻuʻu nohoʻi kona leo (Mar. 7.32), an impediment also in his speech.
ʻū·ʻoki	
ʻū·pī·ʻū	
ʻū·pī·lā·ʻau	
ʻū·pī·huʻa	
ʻū·pī	
ʻū·poʻi	
ʻū·palu	
ʻū·nina	
ʻū·mō·ʻaui·wawe	
ʻū·mō·ʻaui	
ʻū·miʻi·nalo	
ʻū·miʻi·lau

ʻūwī	
ʻūwehewehe	
ʻūpolu	vs. Moist. Ka maka ʻūpolu o ka lehua i ka ua, the soft petals of the lehua wet by the rain.
ʻūpelu	
ʻūpehupehu	vs. Swollen, bloated; inflammation. Cf. pehu 1.
ʻūpaʻipaʻi	
ʻūpa	n. Nippers.
ʻūnina	Var. of ʻūlina.
ʻūmiʻisqueeze	
ʻūmiʻikō	
ʻūmiki	
ʻūlūleo	
ʻūlālelo	
ʻūliʻi	vs. Tiny, wee, petite.
ʻūlinalina	Redup. of ʻūlina.
ʻūlina	vs. Soft, rubbery, plastic. Cf. papālina.
ʻūlilikīnaʻu	
ʻūhū	
ʻūhīʻūhā	vi. Sonorous puffing and blowing sounds, as accompanying the surging of volcanic fires; to puff or blow thus; shish-shish. See ex., nome.

ʻō·hiki	
ʻō·haʻi	
ʻōwelo	vs. Waving slightly, streaming. Cf. kōwelo.
ʻōwaka	
ʻōwae	vi. To crack, fissure, split open, as dry ground; cracked, fissured, gullied. Cf. māwae.
ʻōulaula	
ʻōpūʻōhua	
ʻōpū	
ʻōpē	nvs. Feeble; feebleness. See pē 1. He ʻōpē wale nō kō ʻolua hele ʻana, your walk is quite feeble.
ʻōpuʻupuʻu	1. vs. Lumpy, bumpy, hilly, rough, as cloth or a road. 2. n. Knuckle, as on fingers, wrist. 3. n. Shore fish listed by Malo (no data). (Malo 46.)
ʻōpuʻuhame	
ʻōpuʻuahi	
ʻōpuʻu-ka-honua	
ʻōpule	1. Same as ʻōpulepule 2. 2. n. A wrasse (Anampses cuvier, A. godeffroyi); the name may be qualified by the terms lā uli and uli. (Malo 46.) 3. Same as maiʻa koana.
ʻōpuku	
ʻōpu	
ʻōpiowau	
ʻōpiohaliʻa	
ʻōpilopilo	1. nvs. Bad-smelling, as stagnant water; a marshy odor; halitosis. 2. n. Scraps, fragments. Cf. pilo, any kind.
ʻōpilo	1. Same as ʻōpilopilo. 2. vs. Sick, especially when suffering a relapse; breaking out afresh, as a sore. Rare.
ʻōpikoʻula	
ʻōpihipihi	1. nvs. A mere trifle, small thing; tiny, trifling, as a fish or worthless sweet potato. 2. n. Kind of mat, as used for sails.
ʻōpihikao-kapoho	
ʻōpeʻawai	
ʻōpeluaku	
ʻōpelu-nui-kau-haʻalilo	
ʻōpao	
ʻōpalupalu	Similar to palupalu.
ʻōpaha	nvs. Lopsided, flattened on one side, dented, bent in, caved in, misshapen; dent, cavity. ho.ʻō.paha To make lopsided; misshapen.
ʻōpae-ʻula	
ʻōpae-wela	
ʻōpae-kaʻa	
ʻōnihi	
ʻōnehu	
ʻōnaha	vs. Bowlegged, bent over, stooped, bent, arched; curved, crescent-shaped, as the moon; pigeon-toed. ho.ʻō.naha To cause to be stooped, bent, bowlegged; to imitate the walk of a bowlegged person.
ʻōnae·ao	
ʻōnaeao	
ʻōnae-hana	
ʻōmuʻo-ka-honua	
ʻōmoʻo	
ʻōmolemole	Redup. of ʻōmole 2. Kukui ʻōmolemole, a kukui nut finished for a lei, but smooth and without design, less choice than the ioio or ʻōpaka.
ʻōmoleliʻi	
ʻōmilu	1. n. Kind of ulua, a fish, probably Carangoides ferdau, C. gymnostethoides, C. ajax. 2. nvs. A trifle, mere nothing; insignificant. ʻAʻohe ʻano o ia mea, he ʻōmilu, this thing has no significance, it's a mere trifle.
ʻōmeʻo	1. vi. To bud, to unfold, as a blossom; to come into view; to sprout. Cf. meʻo 2. 2. Same as meʻo, nagging.
ʻōmaʻokoʻili	
ʻōmaʻokanihae	
ʻōmali	nvs. Weak, infirm, puny, shriveling, wilting, as of unripe fruit; weakling.
ʻōma	
ʻōlulu	n. A lobelia (Brighamia insignis). Also pū aupaka. Cf. ālula and Neal 816.
ʻōluheluhe	vs. Sagging, drooping, as a potbelly; limp; flabby; soft, as a crab that has shed its shell. ho.ʻō.luhe.luhe To cause limpness, etc.
ʻōlleo	
ʻōliko-ka-honua	
ʻōliko	1. vi. To bud. Cf. liko. 2. n. A small tree, possibly Rapanea helleri, Myrsine hosakae (syn. M. angustifolia, Suttonia angustifolia), a kind of kōlea.
ʻōlemu-kaʻa	
ʻōlelo—	
ʻōleloʻōiwi	
ʻōleloʻana	
ʻōleloua	
ʻōlelopinepine	
ʻōlelonui	
ʻōlelome	
ʻōlelomakuahine	
ʻōlelomakua	
ʻōleloma	
ʻōlelokīkē	nvt. Dialogue, repartee, conversation; to engage in such. Cf. kīkēʻōlelo.
ʻōlelokona	
ʻōlelohawai'i	
ʻōlelohauwawā	
ʻōlelohaole	
ʻōleloe	
ʻōleloana	
ʻōlela	
ʻōlea	
ʻōlaʻolaʻo	vt. To weed, dig, as with an ʻōʻō or spade. ʻAʻole ia e paʻipaʻi ʻia, ʻaʻole hoʻi e ʻōlaʻolaʻo ʻia (Isa. 5.6), it shall not be pruned, nor dug.
ʻōlauniu	
ʻōlau-ka-honua	
ʻōlau	
ʻōlapa-kahuila-o-ka-lani	
ʻōkupu	vi. To sprout, as seeds; to send out shoots, as ti plants; to come forth, as clouds; sprouting, stubbles.
ʻōkupekupe	Redup. of ʻōkupe 1, 2.
ʻōkumu	1. n. Pommel; canoe end-piece. Cf. makuʻu. 2. nvs. Stump; stumpy, blunt, cut off short, coarse. ʻOkumu lau, stump sending out shoots. (PEP kootumu.)
ʻōkuhekuhe	n. Young ʻokuhe, after the hinana stage.
ʻōkomokomo	Redup. of ʻōkomo. ho.ʻō.komo.- komo Redup. of hoʻōkomo.
ʻōkoholā	n. A variety of sweet potato, said to have been introduced during whaling days.
ʻōkakala—goose	
ʻōkakaala	
ʻōkai	Same as ʻōkaikai. Ka ʻōkai makani (For. 4:591), the rough wind.
ʻōiwi—ua	
ʻōiwi—native	
ʻōiwi—a	
ʻōiwito	
ʻōiwihe	
ʻōiwihawaiʻi	
ʻōiohe	
ʻōili	
ʻōiki	vs. Somewhat small, narrow.
ʻōike	
ʻōihoiho	vi. To go downwards, as deep sweet potatoes. (For. 6:125.)
ʻōhūnā	
ʻōhōwai	
ʻōhākīloi	
ʻōhāiʻula	
ʻōhāhā	Same as ʻōhā, lobelia. (Neal 815–8.)
ʻōhíʻa	
ʻōhuna	1. n. Secret, hidden thing. See huna 2. He ʻōhuna nalo ʻole kāu i ka ʻike a kuʻu ʻohe nānā (song), yours is a secret that cannot be hidden from my telescope. 2. Same as ʻōhune 1, 2.
ʻōhumukini	
ʻōhulehule	
ʻōhui	
ʻōhua—he

ʻōhikl-lolo	
ʻōhiki-lolo	
ʻōhiaʻa	
ʻōhewa	vs. Delirious, incoherent, as a drunkard. ho.ʻō.hewa To bring on drunkenness; drunk, incoherent.
ʻōhelo-papa	
ʻōhe	n. A small native tree (Tetraplasandra oahuensis), found only on Oʻahu; much like its relative, the ʻohe-o-kai, but having oblong, entire leaflets. Lit., upland ʻohe.
ʻōhaʻi	vs. Imperfectly healed, as a broken limb. Cf. haʻi 1. ʻAʻohe ikaika kēia lima, he lima ʻōhaʻi, this arm isn't strong, it's imperfectly healed.
ʻōhaohao	Same as ʻōhao 1.

ʻīpukakomoma	
ʻīniseka	
ʻīnikiniki	(sometimes pronounced ʻīnisinisi in songs). Same as ʻiniʻiniki. Makani houhou ʻili, ʻīnikiniki mālie (song), wind that pierces the skin, a gentle pang.

ʻīkaleleonālani	
ʻīikū	
ʻīhepa	Same as hepa, imbecilic.
ʻīamamao	
ʻī-waha-ʻouʻou	
ʻī-loʻi	
ʻī-hālau	
ʻī-emi	
ʻē—ʻo	
ʻē—nā	
ʻē—ma	
ʻē—aloha	
ʻēʻē	1. Redup. of ʻē 1; contrary, peculiar, opposite; adversely. He ʻēʻē wale nō kona manaʻo, his opinion is in opposition. E pale ana i ka wawā lapuwale, a me ke kū ʻēʻē ʻana i ka mea i kapa hewa ʻia he naʻauao (1 Tim. 6.20), avoiding profane babblings and oppositions of the thing falsely called science. ho.ʻē.ʻē To keep away from, avoid. (PPN kesekese, PEP keekee.) 2. n. Yellow underwing feathers of the ʻōʻō, a bird, as used in featherwork. 3. n. Armpit. Also pōʻaeʻae, poʻēʻē; see kuiʻēʻē. (PCP keekee.).
ʻēʻoe	
ʻēʻma	
ʻē·leka	
ʻē·lau	
ʻē·kā	
ʻē·kona

ʻāwilia	
ʻāwikiwiki	1. Redup. of ʻāwiki. 2. n. A vine (Canavalia spp.), native to Hawaiʻi, related to the maunaloa (C. cathartica), but with narrower pods; used for small, temporary fish traps. Also puakauhi. 3. Same as kōʻeleʻele, a seaweed.

ʻāpua-kea	
ʻāpoʻepoʻe	vi. To assemble.
ʻāpoho	nvs. Depression, hollow, hollowed, pitted.
ʻāpiki—aia	
ʻāpekepeke	n. The Kauaʻi ʻelepaio (Chasiempis sandwichensis sclateri).
ʻāpane	1. n. A kind of lehua tree with dark-red flower. 2. Short for ʻapapane, a bird. See ʻōhiʻa ʻāpane. 3. vs. Red, flushed, blushing.

ʻānaehana	
ʻānae	
ʻāmēnia	
ʻāmui	
ʻāluʻa	vs. Old, worn-out, faded, dilapidated; old and wrinkled, as a person.
ʻāloʻiloʻi	1. n. A damselfish (Dascyllus albisella). Also loʻiloʻi. The young stage is ʻā or ʻaʻā. He ʻāloʻiloʻi ka iʻa waha iki o ke kai, a damsel, small-mouthed fish of the sea [one with little to say]. 2. vs. Humble. Kū ʻāloʻiloʻi i ka hale o ke akua (prayer to Pele), standing humbly in the house of the god. 3. Same as loʻiloʻi 1.

ʻupāpalu	1. Same as ʻūpalupalu 1. 2. n. The larger cardinal fishes, Apogon spp., Apogonichthys perdix, Foa brachygramma. A var. name is ʻupāpalu maka nui.

ʻuporu	
ʻupi	
ʻupena-luʻu	
ʻupe	1. Same as io, a rib on a paddle. 2. n. Spear point. Paʻa loa i loko o ka ʻupe o ka ihe (For. 4:469), firmly stuck within the spear point.
ʻupaʻi	vi. To flap, as wings, clothes in the wind; to bend in the wind, as a branch; to walk with a flapping movement. Mehe ʻupaʻi na ke koaʻe lā (PH 101), like the flapping of a tropic bird's [wings].

ʻulaʻa	Var. of hulaʻa, kulaʻa. He hina nō ka ʻaʻaliʻi kū makani, he ʻulaʻa pū me ka lepo, the wind-resisting ʻaʻaliʻi falls, [but] is uprooted together with the dirt [said of a strong warrior].

ʻuhili	
ʻuhihipili	
ʻuhi	
ʻuhene	nvt. interj. To play a merry tune, converse quietly and romantically, tease coquettishly; exclamation of exultation, as in songs; happy or joyous sound. Cf. henehene. Ua ʻuhene maila lākou i ka mele, they played a merry tune. ʻUhene ahahana kaʻu lei, naʻu ia (song), oh joy, oh boy; she's my darling.

ʻoʻō-a-moa—a	
ʻoʻuholmuai	
ʻoʻoʻpu	
ʻoʻopuē	
ʻoʻopuloa	
ʻoʻopukai	n. A native variety of taro, so named as the leaf stem is similar in coloring to the salt-water ʻoʻopu (the fish), being yellow-green with dark-purple markings. The corms are used mainly as table taro, the leaves often for lūʻau. Grown chiefly in uplands of Kona, Hawaiʻi. The name may be qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and ʻulaʻula.
ʻoʻomano	
ʻoʻolā-maka-pehu	
ʻoʻolā	1. Short for ʻoʻolapū. 2. Same as ʻoʻololā, young of fish.
ʻoʻolola	
ʻoʻo-a-moa	
ʻoʻililepa	
ʻoʻili	
ʻoʻilepa	Short for ʻōʻili lepa, a fish.
ʻoʻeʻoʻe	Redup. of ʻoʻe. I hoʻi iho au e moe, ʻoʻeʻoʻe ana kō ia lā kuli (song), I went back to sleep, but his knees kept prodding. Kino ʻoʻeʻoʻe (Malo 46), body with spiked protuberances, as of a fish.
ʻoʻeaʻe	
ʻoāʻoā	
ʻo·maʻo·haku	
ʻowāwa	
ʻowā	
ʻowena	
ʻowe	
ʻouʻou	1. Redup. of ʻou 1. Nuku ʻouʻou, long protruding nose, as of a swordfish [sometimes said of gossips]. I ka lālā wēkiu ka pua o Lono, i ka ʻouʻou o nā lani nui (kāhili chant), in the topmost branch the flowers of Lono, among the highest of the high chiefs. hō.ʻou.ʻou To jut, project, cause to puncture, etc. 2. nvi. A sharp sound, as of a tapa mallet or of a tapping knee drum; to sound thus. 3. Same as ʻou 2. (PCP koukou.)

ʻopūkahaʻia	
ʻopūhemo	
ʻopunohu	
ʻopuna	
ʻopu-ʻohua	
ʻopoe	
ʻopi·hia	
ʻopiuma	n. 1. Opium. Eng., See ex., māilo. 2. The Manila tamarind (Pithecellobium dulce), from tropical America, both cultivated and wild in Hawaiʻi. It is a medium-sized tree, a legume, with long slender branches, four-parted leaves, whitish flowers in small round heads, and red, twisted pods. Round, flat, black seeds embedded in white, edible pulp were thought to resemble commercial opium, hence the name. (Neal 399–401.)

ʻomaka	
ʻolēʻolē	1. n. A small conch shell. Cf. ʻolē 1. 2. Redup. of ʻolē 2; to rant. Kani ʻolēʻolē ka waha o ka uila, the mouth of the lightning makes an incessant noise [of a garrulous person]. 3. nvs. Wide-mouthed grin, as of an idol; to grin thus.
ʻolāʻolā	Redup. of ʻolā. See ex., lohena. ʻOlāʻolā ka ihu, to snore with short puffs. hō.ʻolā.ʻolā To cause gurgling; to gargle. E hele e hōʻolāʻolā i ka puʻu, go and gargle for your throat.

ʻiʻimo	vi. To blink. Cf. ʻimo, ʻimoʻimo. ho.ʻiʻimo To blink rapidly; to twinkle, to cause a twinkling.

ʻinu	
ʻino—nui	
ʻinoʻoe	
ʻinoo	
ʻinoa	
ʻiniʻiniki	1. vt. To pinch or nip repeatedly; tingling, as with cold. Ka ʻiniʻiniki mālie a ke kēhau, gentle chill [or pang] of misty rain. 2. n. A way of catching small eels by holding bait on the palm of the hand and clenching the fist when the eels come.

ʻiliʻ	
ʻili·ʻili	
ʻili·wehi	
ʻili·wai	
ʻili·oki	
ʻili·noe	
ʻili·kuapo	
ʻili·kai	
ʻiliwehi	
ʻiliole	
ʻilioki	
ʻilimai	
ʻilikūkahi	
ʻilikole	1. nvs. Poverty-stricken, very poor, destitute; pauper (stronger than ʻilihune). Lit., bare skin. hō.ʻili.kole To cause poverty. He keiki hōʻilikole, a child that makes paupers [of the parents, as with expenses]. 2. n. Flesh of half-ripe coconut.
ʻiliki	1. nvt. To strike suddenly, pour down, as rain; onset, striking, downpour. ʻIliki ke kai i ka ʻopeʻope lā, lilo, sea strikes the bundles, gone. Ka ʻiliki a ka ua a hana mao ʻole i ke kai a ka Hinaliʻi, sudden downpour of rain, constant without cessation in the flood of Hinaliʻi. 2. n. A varnish, as made of candlenut bark, ti root, banana stump, and other plants.
ʻilii	
ʻilihia	n. A kind of haʻiwale (Cyrtandra begoniaefolia), on East Maui, having unequal heart-shaped leaves.
ʻilihe	
ʻilieʻe	n. Wild plumbago (Plumbago zeylanica), a native of tropics of the Eastern Hemisphere to Hawaiʻi, a shrub with white tubular flowers and thin, oval leaves that were used medicinally; the sap was used to blacken tattoo marks. (Neal 667.) Also ʻiliheʻe, hilieʻe; lauhihi on Niʻihau.

ʻihiʻawaʻawa	n. Storm accompanied by much thunder and lightning, and an epithet for the gods of thunder and lightning. Lit., stormy sacred ones.

ʻeʻpa	
ʻeʻeʻe	Redup. of eʻe 1; to keep climbing over everything, as an active child; mischievous.
ʻeʻepe	
ʻeʻelokoa	
ʻeʻelekū	Redup. of ʻelekū; blackened or darkened, as leaves or fruit due to maturity or to pelting by storms; dark, gloomy, as clouds. Ma ia malama ua ʻeʻelekū ka lani i nā ao ua … a ua ʻeʻelekū hoʻi nā lau o nā lāʻau a me nā mea ulu i ke oʻo (Kep. 93), in this month the sky is dark with rain clouds … and the leaves of trees and growing things are dark with maturity. Ma ia malama o Nana, ua pau ka ʻeʻelekū o ka lau o nā lāʻau i ka noke a ka ua ma nā lā o ka hoʻoilo (Kep. 89), in this month of Nana, the dark bruising of the leaves of trees by the pelting of the rains of the days of winter has ceased.
ʻeʻelekoa	vs. Stormy. Kū ʻia ka malama ʻeʻelekoa, weathered the stormy month [to have endured hardships].
ʻeʻeiao	Rare. var. of pepeiao, ear. Mō ka ʻeʻeiao o ka puaʻa, cut off is the ear of the pig.
ʻeʻehi	Same as hehi, to step on. ʻEʻehi ihola ia a paʻa, he placed his feet down and stood firm.

ʻaʻahu-wela	
ʻaʻaho	1. n. Thatch purlin; rails, as in a fence. See ʻahohui, ʻahopiʻo, ʻahopueo. Pā ʻaʻaho, corral, rail fence. 2. nvt. Container, as for pia, arrowroot starch; to put pia in small packages so that it may keep sweet. Rare.

ʻapu—ka	
ʻapuʻawa	
ʻapuʻapu	1. vs. Cup-shaped. (PPN kapukapu.) 2. n. Type of agricultural land, as for sweet potatoes, mentioned in 1848 land claims, perhaps a pocket-like area.
ʻapuwai	n. A variety of taro: its corm is used for poi and table taro, its leaves for lūʻau. Varieties are white (kea) and red (ʻula).
ʻapuka	
ʻapuakea	
ʻapo·manaʻo	
ʻapowale	n. A native variety of wet-land taro grown chiefly for poi. Ē! loaʻa akula ke kalo, ʻo ka ʻapowale, O, you get taro, to grasp-foolishly taro [a waste of time, pun on ʻapo wale, to grasp needlessly].

ʻapapa	
ʻapana-poʻo	
ʻapakau	vt. To seize, lay hold of, disarrange, displace; to spread, as sunlight. Ka ʻapakau ʻana iho o nā kukuna a ka lā maluna a ka ʻili o ke kai, the spreading of the rays of the sun on the surface of the sea.

ʻanonoho	
ʻanonanona	Same as naonao and nonanona, ant. E hele ʻoe i ka ʻānonanona, e nānā i kona ʻaoʻao e ho ʻonaʻauao iho (Sol. 6.6), go to the ant, study her ways and learn. The newspaper Ka Nonanona (1841–5) was named for this saying.

ʻalameka	
ʻalalauā	n. Young of the red ʻāweoweo fish. Appearance of schools of this fish near shore was an omen that royalty would die. Also ʻalauwā.

ʻakola	Same as ʻaikola, gesture and expression of contempt.
ʻakoa	n. A small tree resembling koa; dye was made from its bark, and to color tapa. (And.) But cf. kūʻoulena.

īloli

īlamuku	
īkāne	
īkālia	
īkā	1. nvi. To drift upon, strike against; to turn aside from a straight course; flotsam and jetsam. Paʻa ʻia iho i ka hoe uli i ʻole e īkā i ke koʻa, grasp the steering paddle lest [we] strike the coral head. Īkā ihola lākou i lalo i kahi wiliau, ili ihola ka moku (Oih. 27.41), and falling into a place where two seas met [currents mixed] they ran the ship aground. hoʻo.ī.kā. To put or throw ashore; to float, strike, drift. 2. n. Sides of taro patch or garden. Rare.

āwaʻa	
āwawa-malu	
āwai	
āulu	1. vi. Rough, raging, as sea or wind; to injure, harm, rage. 2. vi. To grow. 3. n. A tall endemic tree (Pisonia sandwicensis), with large, oblong, dark-green leaves; small, rounded flower heads, narrow, sticky fruits, and very soft wood. Cf. kaulu, pāpala kēpau. 4. Same as ʻālaʻa 1, Planchonella spp. 5. Same as lonomea, Sapindus oahuensis.

wāwahia	Pas/imp. of wāwahi. Ua wāwahia, ua nāhāhā, ua heleleʻi ka papa (chant), split, shattered, crumbled foundation. (PCP waawa(a)sia.)

pūʻiʻika	
pūʻiwaʻiwa	Redup. of pūʻiwa; to shy, as a horse; excitable, as a horse that is easily frightened.
pūʻawaiiʻi	
pūʻalikaua	
pūʻai	v. To share a little food, take potluck. See puʻu 9.

pūweu	
pūukiuki	
pūpūkanioe	
pūpū-ʻōpae	
pūpuʻu	
pūpalaʻai	
pūolani	
pūokōko	
pūnonohu	Redup. of pūnohu 1. Ulu pūnonohu, to grow round and full at the base, rather than tall and spindly. Ka ua pūnonohu ʻula i ka nahele (UL 110), the rising red rain in the forest. hoʻo.pū.nonohu Caus/sim.
pūniu—ka	
pūnini	vi. To tack, as a ship; to float here and there, drift. hoʻo.pū.nini Caus/sim. Ke hoʻopūnini maila ka iʻa, the fish are drifting here.
pūnihi	vs. Lofty, majestic, dignified. Rare.
pūnaneo	
pūnae-wele	
pūmauʻu	
pūlo	
pūlepe	vt. To turn over, reverse. Rare.
pūlehunui	
pūlamaʻia	
pūlamahia	
pūlaipela	
pūkoʻakoʻa	1. Redup. of pūkoʻa 1, 2. Hina-ka-ʻōno-hipūkoʻakoʻa (name), Hina the many-colored rainbow bit. 2. n. A somewhat calcified green seaweed (Halimeda sp.), erect but not stiff, about 10 cm high, branching and spreading in fan shape, with round to triangular, flattened joints. Used medicinally, pounded up with laukahi (Plantago) and applied as a poultice to boils. The name may be qualified by the terms lau liʻi and lau nui.
pūkowi	
pūkona	
pūkoko	vs. To appear red, as sunset glow or blood. E pūkoko ana ka lā i ke kai (chant), the sun shines red in the sea. (PCP puutoto.)
pūkeu	
pūkaʻo	
pūkalakī	vs. Rough, boisterous, as wind; ruffled, mussed, tousled, disheveled, uncombed, as hair. Fig., bad temper; gruff.
pūipu	
pūili	
pūia	
pūhāpūhā	
pūhāloa	
pūhāhā	Redup. of pūhā 4. Fig., to speak loudly, harshly, or evilly of others.
pūhā-loa	
pūhihio	vi. 1. To whirl, blow, as wind; gusty. 2. To break wind noiselessly. ʻAi pūhihio, same as ʻai pūhiʻu (see pūhiʻu 2).
pūheʻeʻmiki	
pūheoheo	1. n. A whistle sometimes blown during the game of pūhenehene; the answer of the players when addressed by the guesser in the game of pūhenehene (Malo 218) and perhaps also in the game of kilu. 2. Same as pūheheo.
pūhaʻu	
pūhau-kole

pā­lehua	
pāwaina-zeʻeba	
pāwaiho	
pāulu	
pāuli	nvs. Dark, as sea or skin; gloom, darkness. Ua hoʻi ka pāuli makani kualau (For. 5:91), the gloomy wind showers have gone. He pāuli hiwa na ka ua haoa, deep gloom of the pelting rain.
pātausani	
pārau	
pāpūululāʻau	
pāpūho	
pāpīhā	
pāpāono	Redup. of pāono. Ā ʻo ua poʻe mea ola lā ʻehā, ua pāpāono lākou i nā ʻēheu (Hoik. 4.8), and the four beasts had each of them six wings.
pāpālima	1. Redup. of pālima 1. 2. vs. Confirmed, as an agreement by striking hands. hoʻo.pā.pā.lima To touch hands as in making an agreement.
pāpāle	
pāpākolu	Redup. of pākolu.
pāpākole-koaʻe-o-lele-kea	
pāpākahi	Redup. of pākahi. Miki pāpākahi, to dip up poi with one finger.
pāpāialaka	
pāpāia	n. An offering or place for offering, as of kava.
pāpā-miloliʻi	
pāpuhene	Same as pūhenehene, the game.
pāpohaku	
pāpiomakaliʻiliʻi	
pāpi	
pāpaʻíkou	
pāpaʻaʻina	n.v. To crackle, snap; crackling, snapping; sharp crack, as of something breaking, or of crackling sound of feet walking over a crusty surface; to crack, as joints; brittle, easily broken. Cf. ʻuʻina.
pāpaʻanā	Same as paʻapaʻanā 1, 2. E pāpaʻanā mai ʻoe e kōkua mai iaʻu, haste thee to help me.
pāpaʻanui-poloai	
pāpaʻamoi	
pāpaʻaloko	
pāpaʻa-ʻea	
pāpaʻa-lā	
pāpapa-iki	
pāpale—no	
pāpalealiʻi	
pāpakiʻi	
pāoʻolēkei	
pāoʻokauila	
pāoni	nvt. Disagreement, argument, contention; to argue, quarrel; envy (Biblical). hoʻo.pā.oni To cause quarrel, strife; to argue.
pāoehoe-nui-a-lonohea	
pānūnū	Perhaps the same as pānuhunuhu, or a different type of uhu.
pānīʻau	
pānāhāhā	
pānoa	1. vs. Easily taken, of a woman at the beck and call of any man. Lit., touch freely. 2. n. Lightweight wood. Rare.
pāniniʻawaʻawa	
pāniniu	
pāneʻeneʻe	Redup. of paneʻe; to move on little by little, slowly. hoʻo.paneʻe.neʻe Redup. of hoʻopaneʻe; to keep putting off, etc.
pānaʻiahākea	
pānanaiki	Same as pālanaiki.
pāmalō	1. vs. Dry, rainless 2. vi. To thunder without rain. 3. vs. Expressionless, without animation or facial expression; dull, as a party.
pāmaloʻo	Var. of pāmalō 1–3.
pāmalae	
pāmaila	
pālāmoi	n. Second growth stage of the moi, a fish, about 13 cm long (Kauaʻi); third growth stage, about 30 cm long (Hawaiʻi).
pālu	
pālokeʻiʻi	
pāloa	1. Same as pākuʻipai; long seine, as used for mullet. (PCP paaloa.) 2. n. A fish (no data).
pāleoleo	Redup. of pāleo.
pālele	
pālaʻau	
pālaʻai	
pālalahuakiʻi	
pālahlaha	
pāla-ka-hā	
pākū-lena	
pākīpika—ʻaloʻalo	
pākīkī	Same as pākiʻi 2.	1. Redup. of pākī 1; to crush, as pandanus aerial roots with a stone in order to obtain fibers for kava strainers. hoʻo.pā.kī.kī Redup. of hoʻopākī. (PCP paatiitii.) 2. n. A variety of poisonous crab, said to be the same as kūmimi.
pākīkipa	
pākīfika	
pākī-lehua	
pākēlā	
pākālā	
pākukui	1. nvi. Shiftless, vagabond; to wander; to play the wanton; to nibble but not take the hook, of fish. 2. n. A method of enriching the soil for taro plantings by use of kukui leaves, which in rocky areas were covered with dirt in order to make soil. Lit., candlenut enclosure. (Kep. 153.)
pākukau	
pākoʻa	
pākole	1. Var. of pōkole, short. hoʻo.pā.kole Var. of hoʻopōkole. 2. n. A fish (no data). 3. vs. Uncertain. Rare.
pākiʻo	vi. To settle in pools, as rain water; to drizzle; to evacuate the bowels.
pāki·huila	
pākipīka	
pākikakika	Redup. of pakika. hoʻo.pā.kika.kika Redup. of hoʻopakika.
pāki-huila	
pākeupali	vs. Excessively great, greatly exceeding. Ka pākeupali aku o ke kuko, the excessiveness of the lust.
pāke	
pākaʻapohe	
pākaukauʻaʻole	
pākanahiku	
pākali	1. vt. To dole out little by little; to decoy fish by doling out bait little by little; a decoy. Cf. kali, to wait. 2. Also batari n. Battery. Eng.
pākakahi	vt. To distribute one at a time to several; scattered, here and there, as light rain. Cf. kakahi, pākahi, Gram. 10.3. E pākakahi aku i ka iʻa i kamaliʻi, giving the children fish one each, or one at a time.
pākahi—ʻaʻole	
pāina	n. Wedding feast or reception.
pāhuʻa	Similar to kīpuka 1, said especially of clear areas in pastures where it is easy to rope cattle.
pāhune	
pāhumuhumu	
pāhulu

pāhilihurricane	
pāhilicyclone	
pāhihi	vi. To spread, as vines; to stream, as water over a cliff.
pāhemo	
pāhaʻohaʻoto	
pāhaʻohao	
pāhau	1. n. Striped flatfish. (KL. line 156.) 2. nvs. Person who cared for chief's food and clothes; well-cared for, as clothes. Rare. 3. vt. To filch. Rare.

punaua	
punapuna	1. vs. Mealy, firm, not soft or soggy, as taro or sweet potato. 2. Redup. of puna 3; jointed. He punapuna nohoʻi e like me ke kō (For. 5:607), jointed too, like sugar cane [of kava]. (KL. line 60.) 3. vs. Scattered, wind-blown, pulverized. Rare.

pumahoe	
puluʻaha	n. A snare used to catch shrimps and small fish, made of sennit and coconut midrib. Lit., sennit husk. Pepeiao puluʻaha, a snare ear [an ear used for carrying a snare rather than for hearing and obeying, a term of contempt].

poniohua	
ponimōʻī	n. The introduced carnation or pink (Dianthus caryophyllus), a plant widely cultivated for its attractive and spicy-fragrant flowers, one of the commonest flowers used for leis. The Hawaiian name resulted from confusing the English name with "coronation" (Neal 345–6.)	n. The sweet william (Dianthus barbatus), a relative of the carnation, grown in gardens for its abundance of small, bright-colored flowers. (Neal 346.)

polepolemoana	
polepole	1. Rare. var. of palepale, to ward off. 2. n. A child's game. The children put their clenched fists on top of each other; each child makes a wish or suggests a game to play, and sings a chant such as the following: Polepole ka mamalihini, kaʻa mai kaʻa mai i kou, i kou kauhale ʻouʻou; ke ʻākia nei kuʻu piko e kaulele lā e kō lā ē, ward off the strangeness, roll here, roll here the kou wood, for a kou house, a high house; [there's a nip at my navel to make an effort to accomplish.

piʻipiʻi-lau	
piʻiiʻi	
piʻiiani	
piʻiaʻela	
piʻianaiʻi	
piʻianaia	
piʻialiʻi	n. A native variety of taro, one of the oldest varieties grown in Hawaiʻi; formerly known as one of the royal taros and desirable as an offering to the gods; today, an important wet-land poi taro. Leaves and corm are tinged with pink. (HP 28, Whitney.) This name may be qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, ʻulaʻula. See ex., hanoa.

paʻawela	nvt. A burned area; a scar from burning; to burn. Ma kahi maikaʻi e paʻawela ana nō (Isa. 3.24), instead of beauty, burning. 2. n. Probably a wrasse fish.
paʻawaha	n.v. Gag; to gag the mouth (Hal. 39.1). Lit., make the mouth solid.

pauʻole	
pauʻoe	
pauʻakaʻaka	1. Redup. of pauʻaka 1–3. 2. Same as makuʻu 1 and moamoa 2. 3. n. Neck in a house rafter. (Malo 120.)
pauʻaka	1. vs. Grotesque, odd. Ua kālai pauʻaka ʻia ke poʻo o ke kiʻi, the head of the image is carved grotesquely. hoʻo.pau.ʻaka To make grotesque, odd. 2. vt. Damaging; unreliable, deceitful; to disturb, Mai pauʻaka mai ʻoe i ka hana a mākou, don't you disturb our work. 3. vs. Of no use, fruitless, unproductive, without reward or profit, discouraging. hoʻo.pau.ʻaka Same as above. 4. n. Quail, so called because of its song. Rare. See manu kapalulu.

pale·ʻeke	
pale·ʻea	
pale·upoʻo	
pale·maʻi	
pale·kona	
palewāwae	1. n. The joy weed (Alternanthera amoena), a small herb front Brazil, used as a low border for paths and flower beds. It has red, branching stems and variegated red, green, and yellow, small oval leaves. (Neal 334.) 2. Small, fan-shaped brown seaweeds (two species of Padina [P. commersonii, light-brown, and P. vickersiae, larger, darker-brown]), common on the reef, each fan more or less split and curled. Not eaten.
palewawae—he

pahuu	
pahupū	vs. Cut in half, cut in two, severed, cut short, chopped off. Nui pahupū, of uneven size; poorly proportioned, as overly large buttocks, shoulders; unsymmetrical. E ʻoki ʻo mua me hope o ka waʻa ā pahupū (FS 187), sever the bow and stern of the canoe, completely sever.

nāwiliwiliprivate	
nāwiliwilika	
nāwaīokalaniʻōpuʻu	
nāwao	1. n. A domesticated taro that has gone wild in the forest, (wao). (Kaʻū name). A native taro cultivated in Puna. Hui aku, hui mai, hui kalo me ka nāwao, mixed here, mixed there, mixed wild taro with tame taro [utter confusion]. 2. Same as nākea, a fish. 3. (Cap.) Same as Mū ʻai maiʻa, a mythical people.

nākuʻiʻelua	
nākuʻi	nvi. To rumble, roar, thump; rumbling; beating, as the heart; thrilled (perhaps naku 1 + -ʻi, transitivizer: Gram. 6.6.4). Ka nākuʻi o ka pū kuni ahi, the roar of the cannon. hoʻo.nā.kuʻi Caus/sim.

nāhiʻenaʻenakekapuokeōpūolani	
nāhiʻenaʻenaikekapuewelaai-kapēkapuokeakua	
nāhili	vs. Blundering, confused, perplexed, wandering off the course; careless, awkward. I hea aku nei lā i nāhili ai ka ʻau waʻa? Where did the canoe fleet wander off to? hoʻo.nā.hili To cause a blundering, wandering, as by misdirecting; to procrastinate, waste time through blundering.

nupanupa	Redup. of nupa 1–3. Also lupalupa. Cf. hānupanupa. hoʻo.nupa.nupa Same as hoʻolupalupa. Ua piha kā kākou mau mele me nā hoʻonupanupa ʻana a ia mea, he aloha, our songs are filled with lush [descriptions] of that thing, aloha.

mokupipi	
mokupawa	vi. To break, come intermittently. Cf. pawa 1. Ua like me ka ʻeku ʻana a ka puaʻa ka mokupawa o ka ʻāina, the breaking up of the soil is like a pig's rooting. E mokupawa ai ka ua mahina ʻai, the farming rains are intermittent.

meʻohelo	
meʻoe	
meʻo	1. vt. To nag and tease, usually indirectly; to drool at the mouth while watching, as food being prepared; to linger about with greedy eyes; importuning. Meʻo maoli kēia kamaliʻi i ka mea ʻai, these children are begging, watching, reaching for the food. 2. vi. To sprout.

maʻonakala	
maʻomaʻo	1. nvs. Green, greenness. ʻAno maʻomaʻo, somewhat green, greenish. hoʻo.maʻo.maʻo To paint green, make green. 2. n. A green tapa, as of māmaki bark.

maʻamauma	
maʻalua	
maʻaloa	n. A low native shrub (Neraudia melastomaefolia), related to the māmaki, and like it, having strong bark formerly used for making tapa. Also ʻoloa, maʻoloa.

malilda	
malila	1. vs. Ghostly, shadowy. ʻO ka malila mōhai a Ka-ulu-lani, nona ke aka ka hihiʻo i ka pō nei (chant for Kua-kini), the ghostly offering of Ka-ulu-lani, to him belonged the shadow, the fleeting dream of last night. 2. Common pronunciation of malaila, there, but not so written.

maiapilo	n. A low, smooth shrub (Capparis sandwichiana) with vinelike branches, a member of the caper family, growing on some beaches and lava flows; leaves rounded-oblong; flowers white, pea-shaped, 5 cm long, with four petals surrounding a mass of long white stamens, open and fragrant only at night. (Neal 368–9.) Also pilo, pua pilo.

lōkō	
lōkea	n. 1. Long European knife with a white handle. 2. Child of a nīʻaupiʻo, piʻo, or naha chief, whose mother was related to him but of a junior line. (Kam. 64:5–6.)

līwaiakalaniʻōpuʻu	
līpehu	
līpe	
līpahapaha	n. A general term for sea lettuce (Ulva fasciata and Monostroma oxyspermum), common green seaweeds with delicate broad blades, usually with wavy margins. Eaten as a minor element mixed with other tastier seaweeds. Also ʻīliohaʻa, līpaha, lipāilahalaha, pahapaha (probably restricted to Kauaʻi), pakaiea (restricted to Hawaiʻi), and pālahalaha (Maui, Molokaʻi, and Oʻahu).

lā—he	
lāʻō	1. Same as lau kō, sugar-cane leaf. 2. n. A bright-colored greenish fish, about 1.3 cm long (Halichoeres ornatissimus).
lāʻīē	
lāʻīpala	n. A bright-yellow reef fish (Zebrasoma flavescens). Lit., yellow ti leaf. Also lauʻīpala, laukīpala.

lālei	nvs. Cluster, bunch, as of bananas; assembled together, as flowers in a lei. Rare. hoʻo.lā.lei To gather together, as flowers.
lālauahi	vs. Gray, stormy-looking, smoke-colored. Makehewa iā kāua ke hele, ke lālauahi maila ʻo uka, it would be a mistake for us to go, it's threateningly gray inland.

lonohiʻi	vi. To cry to be carried, of an infant carried too much; to fret in a spoiled way to be carried. Lit., hear carry. Mai hiʻi mau ʻoukou o lonohiʻi kēia keiki, don't keep carrying this child or he'll want to be carried always.

loloiāhili	vs. To wander, as one lost; to stray, dilly-dally; to digress and wander in speech; roundabout. hoʻo.lolo.iā.hili Same as above. Me ka hoʻololoiāhili ʻole aku, without further digression.
loloihi	
lolohili	Var. of loloiāhili.
lolohe	1. Redup. of lohe; to listen carefully, attentively, with good hearing. He pepeiao lolohe, an ear with good hearing. hoʻo.lolohe To iisten carefully; to strain the ear to hear. He aliʻi ʻo ka lani, he moʻopuna na Lono, he hiapo na ke kini, hoʻololohe ua (chant), the heavenly one is a chief, a descendant of Lono, the first-born of a multitude [of long lineage], a listener to the rain [unafraid of rain because of high rank]. 2. vs. Stubborn; hard to move, as a rock. Rare. Cf. hoʻokololohe. hoʻo.lolohe Caus/sim.
loloha	Redup. of loha, to droop.

liʻoliʻo	1. vs. Bright, dazzling, dazzled. Also liko 2, lile 1, lino 1. hoʻo.liʻo.liʻo Caus/sim. (PCP likoliko.) 2. Var. of liʻo: name of the sound made by the ʻaʻo bird; to call thus. 3. Redup. of liʻo.

kūʻaihele	
kūākāhili	n. One of high birth who stands by a kāhili feather standard, beside the high chief, in contrast to the paʻa kāhili who carries the kāhili.

kūpū	vs. Thick, as gravy, or moisture-laden lomi fish; to jell. hoʻo.kū.pū Caus/sim.; to thicken.

kūpe'e	
kūpaʻu-keʻanae	
kūpaʻi	nvi. Heap, pile, stack, lot; to pile, stack, heap up, as in a disorderly fashion. Kūpaʻi ke aloha nou, ē Kīnaʻu, a great deal of love for you, O Kīnaʻu. Kūpaʻi ka ukana ma ka uwapo, the freight is piled up on the wharf.
kūpaʻewa	vs. Imperfect. Hakina kūpaʻewa, improper fraction.
kūpaʻanā	
kūpaʻahaʻaheo	
kūpau	vs. 1. Entirely finished. 2. Fearful, shrinking. Rare.
kūpapakū	nvi. Bedrock; to stand on bedrock; depths of the earth.
kūpalalakē	
kūpa'a	
kūo	
kūnānahu	
kūnāhīhī	
kūnuʻunuipuawalau	
kūnuiakea	
kūninihi	
kūnini	Rare. var. of kūnihi 1, 2.
kūneki	vi. Filled to overflowing; to flow away. Kūneki nā kūʻauhau liʻiliʻi, noho mai lalo, hoʻokahi nō ʻo kō ke aliʻi piʻi i ka ʻiʻo; let the small genealogies flow away; keep [them] down; one indeed, the chief's who ascends. [Advice to youngsters to respect the senior line and not talk of their own relationship to it].
kūne	
kūnaʻi	Same as kūnaʻina. hoʻo.kū.naʻi Caus/sim.
kūnaka	
kūmūnuiʻaiake	
kūmū-nui-ʻai-ake	
kūmū-aʻe	
kūmīkini	
kūmālima	
kūmāiwa-ʻumi	
kūmāiwa-iwakālua	
kūmāhoa	
kūmāhiku	
kūmā-iwa	
kūmuhana	
kūmuamu	
kūmoena	n. 1. Long strip commencement of a mat. 2. Pile of mats; spread out as a mat or landscape. Kūmoena weuweu, pile of mats with grass or leaves sandwiched between the upper and lower layers, used for sleeping out-of-doors. ʻOia kūmoena kalukalu hoʻi o Ka-paʻa, that expanse of kalukalu grass of Ka-paʻa.
kūmimi	n. Small crabs such as Lophozozymus intonsus. Varieties are kūmimi mākaʻo (Petrolisthes coccineus) and kūmimi pua (Lybia tesselata). Both were used in sorcery and are inedible.
kūmikini	
kūmene	vs. Blunt, flat, of the nose. hoʻo.kū.mene Caus/sim.
kūmanakua	
kūmakua	1. Same as ʻāhihi 2, a lehua bush. 2. (Cap.) n. Name of a strong wind.
kūmakaia	
kūmahumahu	
kūlōʻihi	vt. To wait a long time; to stand long; to last long, endure; to take a long time. E hana kūlōʻihi aku ana kēia, this is work that takes a long time to do.
kūlokuloku	Redup. of kūloku. Also kūnokunoku. Pakapaka ua, paka ua, kūlokuloku (chant), rain of many drops, drops of rain, running, running in streamlets.

kūkahaʻula	
kūkaeloli	nvs. Mildew; mildewed. Mālama o kiʻo kūkaeloli, be careful of mildew. Lit., sea cucumber dung.
kūkaelio	n. 1. Toadstool, mushroom. 2. A name for unidentified wild grasses growing where horses are pastured. (For. 5:641.) Lit., horse dung.
kūkaehao	nvs. Rust; rusty. Lit., iron excrement. Ua kiʻo kūkaehao, it has become rusty; lit., has excreted rust.

kīpu	
kīponapona	1. Redup. of kipona 1–4. 2. n. A small, climbing, native shrub (Phyllostegia racemosa) in the mint family, with small, downy leaves, and small, purplish-white flowers in whorls.
kīpona	
kīpola	nvt. Wrapper, such as ti leaves about fish; to wrap up, bundle up; to keep warm with wraps, as a sick person.
kīpoka	
kīpapaʻia	
kīpapapōhaku	
kīpaipai	vt. To encourage, inspire.
kīpaepae	n. Stone pavement or steps for entering a house.
kīolaola	1. Redup. of kiola; tossing back and forth or up and down, as in juggling; to cast for fish; to sort and distribute, as sweet potato cuttings (For. 5:665). 2. n. A form of black magic, by which a special stone was prayed over and hurled at a victim; it entered through the anus or mouth and destroyed the victim, and then returned to the magician.	n.v. Horseshoe pitching; to pitch horseshoes.	n. Ringtoss.

kīlauca	
kīkū	vi. To lean back firmly. Niʻihau i ke kīkū (saying), Niʻihau leans firmly back [the people of Niʻihau are independent].
kīkīkoʻu	1. n. Chirping or screeching, as of a flock of birds; deep tone in chanting; tapping noise. Cf. koʻu, to cluck. He nahenahe ma kekahi wahi, ā he kīkīkoʻu ma kekahi wahi o ka mele, soft in some places, deeptoned in other parts of the chant. 2. Redup. of kīkoʻu.

kāʻiʻī	vi. Hard, rigid; stingy, close-fisted, hard-hearted, harsh; to refuse help; to deny a request; to strut pompously; persistent. Cf. ʻiʻī, hard. ʻOluʻolu ʻole au e noho nei ke kani kāʻiʻī a ke oeoe (chant for Ka-piʻolani), I sit here in discomfort, with the persistent, hard blowing of the whistle.

kā	
kāwāwā	
kāwililīpoa	
kāwike	
kāweleʻā	
kāwelewele	1. n.v. Ropes, especially those attached to ʻiako, outrigger booms, to assist in righting a capsized canoe; lines attached to a fish net; person or canoe at the head of a line being pulled. Fig., to recall something almost forgotten; dim memory. Also kākāwelewele. ʻO Kama ke akua i ke kāwelewele, Kama was the god [who held] the end of the rope being pulled. Ā i loaʻa hoʻi ke kāwelewele, pono iki nō ia manawa, when an almost forgotten thought is recalled, it helps a little for the time being. 2. n. Goatee. 3. Redup. of kawele. 4. Redup. of kāwele.

kāpule	vs. Overripe, black or spotted, as a banana skin; fat, as a plover. See ex., Kaʻelo 1. hoʻo.kā.pule To ripen, fatten.

kāmaulele	
kāmalii	
kāmakahala	n. All species of a native genus (Labordia) of forest trees and shrubs. According to William Hillebrand, three species with orange flowers were used in leis for chiefs. See nīoi kāmakahala.	n. A native shrub (Labordia waialealae) with small leaves 1.3 to 2.6 cm long, found only on Mt. Wai-ʻaleʻale on Kauaʻi. Lit., small-leafed kamakahala.

kākonakona	1. n. A native grass (Panicum torridum), 30–70 cm. high, covered with silky, light-colored hairs, the cone-shaped flowering panicle 7.8 to 16 cm long, coated with silky hair. (Neal 73.) See hākonakona. 2. A variety of sweet potato.

kuʻilena	
kuʻikē	1. vi. To toll or ring, as a bell. Ke kuʻikē, kanikē maila nā pele, the bells are tolling and ringing. 2. vt. To pound smooth, level off, raze; to strike right and left indiscriminately; to destroy completely, as in war.

kuʻakuʻai	Redup. of kūʻai; trade, exchange; for sale; to sell repeatedly; to give for the sake of receiving something in return. hoʻo.kuʻa.kuʻai To trade, buy and sell.

kukuʻ	
kukupu	Redup. of kupu, to grow. See prayer, hōʻeu (a). He mau lāʻau hoʻolaha aliʻi ke kukupu nei (chant), these were trees from which chiefs were propagated, that put out new sprouts now.

kukukū	1. Redup. of kukū 1. Kukukū mai auaheʻi nā wāwae o ʻoukou, your feet will likely be pricked by burs. 2. nvi. Sound of boiling water; to sound thus; sputtering.

kolekolea	1. nvi. To cry, of the kōlea, bird; to sing, of the kāhuli, land shell in Hawaiian belief. Fig., a child that runs about wildly. 2. n. Variety of moana, goatfish, perhaps Parupeneus chrysonemus. Rare.

killo	
kiliʻopu	1. vi. Absorbed in an interesting, happy pastime, as love-making; contented. Ua kiliʻopu māua i ka pō nei, what pleasure was love-making for the two of us last night. 2. vs. Graceful, as in running, jumping. 3. (Cap.) Var. of Kiliʻoʻopu, a wind. 4. Same as lele ʻopu, to dive.

kaʻolinani	
kaʻolina	
kaʻolaupoko	
kaʻokaʻo	1. vs. High, lofty, prominent. Fig., conceited. Also kakaʻo. Kaʻokaʻo hoʻi kēlā hale e kau maila i ka puʻu, how prominent is that house placed there on the hill. 2. n. Rain cloud on the point of precipitation; first raindrops. (AP) 3. vs. Hard, arid, especially of red earth. Rare.

kaʻamehaʻi	Var. of kāmehaʻi.
kaʻalā	1. Same as moʻo ʻalā, a lizard. 2. vs. Blind (used with maka). Rare.
kaʻaluna	vi. To sail or turn against the wind. Fig., to dominate; overbearing. Cf. kaʻalalo.

kaumua-lii	
kaumqali	
kaumoʻo	1. nvt. To splice, mend a fracture with a splint; to fasten canoe gunwale; wooden canoe clamp. 2. vs. Perched high. 3. vs. Uncertain, hesitant. ʻAʻole i hoʻomau ʻia ka hana, kaumoʻo wale nō i ke akaaka ʻole, work was not continued, just uncertainty with lack of clarity. 4. v. To point out or determine boundaries of a moʻo land division.

kauahele	
kauaheahe	1. vi. To look or move straight ahead: to gaze. He aha kēia āu e kauaheahe net? What are you gazing at? Kauaheahe ka holo ʻana o kahi kaʻa o mākou, our car went straight on and on. Lele kauaheahe i luna lilo loa, to fly on and on, way far up. hoʻo.kau.ahe.ahe To hover; to fly softly, gently, continuously, at the same speed. 2. vs. Gentle, as a breeze; light. Kaʻao kauaheahe, light story. 3. n. A variety of sweet potato.

kanuo	
kanunu	vs. Large physically, both tall and stout; husky. Kanunu hoʻi kēlā keiki, how large that child is. He heʻe kanunu, an enormous octopus.

kanihia	Pas/imp. of kani 1. Ka poʻe nāna ke aliʻi e noho nei, e noho kanihia aloha aʻe ana iāʻoe (chant for Kua-kini), the people whose chief is present express their great affection for you. (PPN tangisia.)

kalaʻea	vs. Rough, rude in speech. He ʻōlelo kalaʻea wale nō kā Hākau iā ʻUmi, Hākau spoke only roughly to ʻUmi.

kalama-kowali	
kalalī	nvi. To go quickly, briskly, without noticing anyone; to walk or talk in a brisk, haughty way; proud; such activity. Noho ana ka makuahine i ka ʻoluʻolu, hele ke keiki i ke kalalī, the mother stays in comfort, the child goes away with pride [a riddle: the answer is that the mother is the rough tip of a pandanus key, the child is the soft base made into a lei that is proudly worn]. hoʻo.kala.lī Caus/sim.; to hurry.

kalakupua	nvs. Under control of a mysterious or supernatural power; magic. See kupua. hoʻo.kala.kupua Magic; to do wondrous acts; a magician, enchanter, witchcraft; extraordinary fisherman, elusive thief. He ikaika hoʻokalakupua, extraordinary or supernatural strength. See kupua.

kaha—e	
kaha‒kaha	
kahaʻopū	
kahaʻinuiamano	
kahaʻigeorge

kahaʻi-ao-nui-a-piʻikea	
kahaʻi-ao-nui-a-kaulana	
kahaʻi-a-mano	
kahaʻea	n. Cumulus clouds, often colored, thought to be a sign of rain. Cf. ao, ʻōpua. Kau kahaʻea i ka hana waele; palepale nā ʻauwai o lalo, the cumulus clouds appear during the task of weeding; clean the water-courses down below.

ka-ihu-o-ka-puaʻa	n. 1. A type of stone (no data). Lit., the snout of the pig. 2. (Cap.) A lua fighting stroke. (Also without Ka-.)

hōpunaʻōlelo	
hōpulepule	
hōnōai	
hōnēnē	vt. To attract. He lāhui kanaka hōnēnē i nā mea ʻino (Kep. 75), a race of people attracted persistently by sinful things.
hōneʻeneʻe	
hōnau-nau	
hōmīmī	Redup. of hōmī.
hōlua-loa	
hōlokeloke	Same as hālokeloke, loose.
hōliolio	
hōlio	1. n. Two species of small, rare, endemic trees (Cryptocarya) in the laurel family, found only on Kauaʻi and Oʻahu. (Neal 361.) 2. vs. Constantly in mind and thought. Rare.
hōlina	interj. Haul in! Help! Eng.
hōlapa	Same as hoʻolapa. See lapa 1, 2.

hī	
hīpuʻupuʻu	Redup. of hīpuʻu 1, 2.
hīnauulua	
hīnanaē	
hīnana	
hīnalenale	
hīlia	1. Pas/imp. of hili 1–4. He kīʻoki o ke kīkākapu, ʻo ka iʻa kapu hīlia au ʻawahia, stripes of the kīkākapu, the sacred fish, smitten with bitter bile. 2. n. A native bird (no data).
hīkāpōloa	
hīkiʻikiʻi	Redup. of hīkiʻi. (Mat. 27.2.)
hīkapōloa	
hīhīmanu-kaula

hī-puapua

hī-la-hī-la	
hĩhĩmanu	
hē·kī	
hēkuawa	
hē-wa	
hā—a	
hāʻōʻū	
hāʻwi	
hāʻupuʻupu	1. Redup. of hāʻupu; to recall again and again. 2. n. Sprouts from sweet potatoes. Also hāpuʻupuʻu, hāʻapuʻapu.
hāʻupunuimaunakiʻekiʻe	
hāʻupuhe	
hāʻupu-kele	
hāʻuleʻule	Redup. of hāʻule 1–3.
hāʻukuʻuke	
hāʻukeuke	
hāʻuke	1. Same as hāʻukeʻuke 1–3. 2. Same as nāʻuke, to search for lice. Cf. hāʻule 4.
hāʻui	
hāʻino	
hāʻili	Same as hāʻiliʻili. Ka pali hāʻili kauā (KL. line 2094), the cliff that curses the outcast.
hāʻi	
hāʻena—a	
hāʻena-nāpali	
hāʻawiʻia	
hāʻawipioma	
hāʻawina	
hāʻama	vs. To begin to turn yellow, as ripening mango or papaya. Cf. -ʻama.
hāʻaluea	
hāʻalu	Same as hōʻalu.
hāʻale	vs. Completely full and ready to overflow; rippling. Cf. ʻale. Ua hāʻale ka wai i ka lau o ke pili, the stream rose up to the very pili grass. Haʻale i ka wai a ka manu, rippling in the water of birds [an attractive person likened to rippling waters that attracts birds].
hāʻailona

hāweoʻulakaumaka	
hāwaʻewaʻe	n. 1. General name for small lobsters. 2. Sprouts from sweet potatoes.
hāwaiʻi	
hāwai	1. vt. To generate steam in an earth oven by pouring on water (Kep. 163); to purify with water. 2. n. Temporary long, gabled house in which priestesses assembled for purification ceremonies. (Malo 178.) 3. n. Sewer. 4. n. A variety of sweet potato.
hāunu	nvi. A line, as used in lashing a mat canoe cover; to add a new weft in plaiting. Moena hāunu ʻole o ka nahele, mats of the forest without added wefts [a bed of forest ferns and greenery].	Same as unu kupukupu: see unu 2, altar.

hālāliʻi	
hālā-pēpe	
hāluʻa	1. nvs. Stripe, ripple; striped, ridged, seamed, streaked, wrinkled. Cf. ʻālu ʻa. 2. n. Pattern on the surface of a tapa beater or tapa. This term may follow types of beaters, as koʻeau hāluʻa, mole hāluʻa, pūʻili hāluʻa. It also precedes types of beaters, as listed below. 3. Var. of hānuʻa; see nuʻa 1. 4. vs. Empty, as the stomach. Oʻahu.

hākuʻi	vt. To beat, pound, pummel; to echo, reverberate; to flutter, palpitate, thump; to puff, as smoke. hoʻo.hā.kuʻi Caus/sim. Hoʻohākuʻi i koʻu naʻau, shocking to my heart. Hoʻohākuʻi nākolo, blow echoing and reechoing.
hākuʻekuʻe	Same as hāʻukeʻuke.
hākuma	vs. 1. Pock-marked, as by smallpox; ravaged, as by leprosy; coarse, rough, lumpy, pitted; mossgrown. 2. Dark, thick, as clouds. Fig., intense, as love. Cf. mākuma.
hākui	1. vt. To steam, as by placing fish, meat, or vegetables in a sealed calabash with hot stones and a little hot water. (Kep. 161.) 2. n. Spike, as of the hāʻukeʻuke.

huliamahi—	
hulialana	v. To remove the bitterness, especially to pour off the bitter liquid and add fresh water to the preparation of arrowroot (pia). I pau ka hulialana (a prayer; Malo 199), to remove the bitterness. Ka pō luluka me ka hulialani, maʻemaʻe ka ʻāina, kōnalenale ka noho (For. 6:403), the fright of peace and returned tranquillity, clean the land, calm the dwelling.

huhulu	vs. Bristling, tousled, as feathers, fur, body hair.	Intensifier of huhulu. Huhulu iʻi ka hulu o ka manu i ka ua kakahiaka (chant), tousled were the feathers of the bird in the morning rain.	vi. To rise, as fur of an angry dog.	Same as huluhulu weo.

hoʻikaōpūaiʻuwala	
hoʻihā	Intensive of hoʻi 5 (often written as two words). (Gram. 7.5.) E hele hoʻihā kāua, well, let's go then. Maikaʻi hoʻihā, very good indeed. I Hawaiʻi hoʻihā me Pele e noho ai (FS 239), then stay at Hawaiʻi with Pele.

holohnlona	
holohiʻa	vi. To dart this way and that, as children at play; to veer at an angle, miss. Hoʻokūkū, hoʻonānā, nānā kō maka i ka mahina, holohiʻa aku, holohiʻa mai, nui nō ʻoe, nui kō kino (child's game chant), stand about, look about, let your eyes see the moon, run this way, run that way, you are big, big your body.

hoahoaka	1. Redup. of hoaka 3–5. 2. n. Comb of a rooster.
hoahoa	Redup. of hoa 3; a rounded tapa beater (also called hohoa, pepehi); rapid beating, striking, as of tapa or pandanus leaves; a stick beater for washing clothes. Fig., bad-tempered. Keu hoʻi kēia a ke kanaka hoahoa, this person certainly beats the beater [in rage]. hoʻo.hoa.hoa Caus/sim.

hiʻia	Pas/imp. of hiʻi 1. E nā keiki o … Hawaiʻi, hiʻia i ka hana mau ʻia e ka makani anu Ka-laʻi-ākea (chant), o children of Hawaiʻi, sustained by the constant action of the cool Ka-laʻi-ākea wind.

hikikū	
hikikiʻi	vi. 1. To lean back, relax. Ua ʻia kāua e ka ua, hikikiʻi kāua i Kananā, we are rained on, let's lean back and relax at Kananā [pun on kāua, we two, and ka ua, the rain]. 2. To spread, as mist; to rain, especially a slanting rain. Hikikiʻi ka noe i nā pali, the fog slants by the cliffs.

heau	n. 1. Place where fishermen set a basket fish trap, as for hīnālea. 2. Exocarpus spp., native shrubs and small trees (sandalwood family), with more or less leafless, jointed branches. (Neal 325.) Also au 12.

haʻiwale	n. All native species of Cyrtandra, slender soft-wooded forest shrubs with white tubular flowers. (Neal 773.) Sometimes called kanawao keʻokeʻo. See ʻilihia.

haumanumanu	Same as manumanu, irregular, dull; ugly. Haumanumanu ka ipu ʻinoʻino, misshapen is the imperfect gourd [an ugly person; a warning to a mother to mold the body of her baby].

hauhauailiki	
hauhana	nvt. Lashing, as of adze to handle; to lash. (hau 3 + -hana, nominalizer: Gram. 6.6.2.) Cf. imu hau hana. Pale hauhana, cloth protecting (pale) lashing of ʻiako, outrigger boom, to the canoe float. (PNP faʻusanga.)

haoʻe	Var. of haoʻa. Haoʻe nā ʻale o Hōpoe i ka ʻino, the billows of Hōpoe rise in the storm [anger mounting; the seas at Hōpoe, Puna, were notoriously rough].

hakuʻāina	n. Landowner; landlord.
hakuʻili	
hakuʻia	
hakuʻepa	nvt. To deceive, fabricate; liar; malicious gossip; deceitful. Ka poʻe haku ʻepa i kō ʻoukou noho pono ʻana i loko o Kristo (1 Pet. 3.16), the people that falsely accuse your good life within Christ. ʻAʻole pēlā ka ʻoiaʻio, haku ʻepa loko ʻino (song), that is not the truth, malicious fabrications.

aukanunnia	
aukana	Short for au kanaiʻi (see au) 2. Ke aliʻi i makana ai, he koa a he aukana ia, the chief who gave the gift, a warrior and a strong soldier he.

ahulinuikaapeape	
ahulimai	
ahukū	nvt. To stone to death; slaughter by burying the victim under a pile of stones. Hākau, half brother of ʻUmi, was killed in this fashion (FS 141), and this method was used unsuccessfully against the hero Ka-welo (FS 107). Hoʻokahi wale nō kumu e make ai ʻo Ka-welo, ʻo ke kaua i ke ahukū, there was only one way to kill Ka-welo, burial beneath stones.

ahaho	
ahahiuna	
ahahana	Interj. Syllables repeated in chants, usually at ends of verses, similar to ēhē; a taunting singsong teasing phrase, used especially by children, meaning "Oh! Oh! Aha! Shame on you! You are going to catch it!" As a verb, to tease. See ex., lei 1, ʻuhene. Also ahana and ahana kōkō lele, both meaningless. Mai ahahana ʻoe i kou pōkiʻi, don't tease your young brother.
